text: Flying.  Not at the intangible height of a jet, but at spitting distance from the treetops.  We're in central Alaska, the Big Lonely, just north of the Arctic Circle. A thick forest follows the contours of mountain foothills like a deep-pile carpet.  Up at treeline the forest thins tundra, a grassy scruff turning red and yellow with the coming of autumn. On the horizon, the hills rise to meet the Endicott Mountains, a great fortress wall of granite so sharp and jagged that snow cannot stick to its face.  This is how a North America once looked -- raw, indomitable. Then, abruptly coming into the SCENE is a colossal etchin across the landscape too deliberate to be of natural orig Bisecting this country like a metallic ribbon -- or a sca depending on your point of view -- is the 800-mile-long Trans-Alaskan Pipeline. Even the immensity of the pipeline is rendered insignific by the vastness of the land.  It goes on, and on, and on.
A lone MAN walks along the Haul Road, a one-lane gravel trail running parallel to the pipeline.  The weather turn sour -- rough wind and stinging snow cut across the man's path.

The man is ERIC DESMOND, twenty-four, clean-shaven, determined.  He's clearly out of place here, dressed in a business suit and a light, camel-hair topcoat. Eric is trying to follow some footprints in the snow -- a predator's tracks, those of a wolf or coyote.  But the footprints ahead have faded, covered by the snow and wind
The weather becomes more oppressive.  Heavy snow, gale wi and sub-zero temperatures make his progress tortuous.  Er strives stubbornly forward.

Eric has gathered some branches.  He tries to make a fire Moisture from his breath has frozen in the upturned colla of his insufficient coat, and his skin is split raw from cold. His hands are too numb to hold the matches.  After severa attempts at striking one, he slumps down next to the pile wood, exhausted and frustrated.
The snow has covered the pile of branches.  Eric still si next to it, partially covered in snow himself.
His face is a death mask: eyes half-open and dull, lips a purplish blue, bloodless skin crystallizing as it ices ov The wind HOWLS around him.  The snow sticks to his eyelas and hair without melting.

Eric bolts up in bed.  Next to him, ANNE MARIE GAUVIN sit up and hugs him.  All that can be seen of her in the dark a lovely silhouette and a cascade of dark hair.  After a moment, Eric kisses her.  He shakes off the dream and lie back down.
A metal sign, peppered with shotgun holes, is posted near pipeline support piling:

Eric walks quietly past the sign, intent on something ahe of him.  Although still somewhat boyish in appearance, he confident and resolute in attitude.  His clothes have a distinctly western feel: Lucchese boots, Levis 501's, Mah cotton shirt.  His down parka is unzipped in the sunny, windless, forty-degree afternoon.
He pauses, then brings to his shoulder a rifle with a four-power scope mounted atop it.  He peers through the scope.
He puts the crosshairs on the shoulder flank of a big, ivory-white timber wolf, fifty yards away.

Anne Marie stands beside Eric, a Nikon with a telephoto l in her hand, holding her breath in anticipation.  She's twenty-three, pretty, with soft features and piercing blu eyes.  She wears Eddie Bauer woman's gear like she was bo in it. Eric expertly fixes his aim and slowly squeezes the trigg But instead of a loud retort, there is only the dull POP a CO2-powered dart gun.

The tranquilizer dart finds its mark in the wolf's fleshy shoulder.  The wolf takes off running, but almost immediately slows, sits, then lies down. Eric and Anne Marie hurry over to the wolf, who is breath deeply.  Eric kneels next to him and strokes his thick fu
What a beauty. (to Anne Marie) Hand me the transmitter.

Anne Marie passes to Eric a tiny, weatherproof homing dev attached to a steel collar band.  Eric puts the collar loosely around the wolf's neck and crimps it in place, al the while TALKING soothingly to the semi-conscious animal Anne Marie smiles at Eric's tenderness and snaps some photos. With the collar in place and transmitter activated, Eric backs away while the wolf tries to rouse itself from its narcosis.
(continuing) He's coming around fine.
Be right back.  I left my camcorder in the car.
as she hurries back to their International Scout.  On the door of the Scout is a stylized logo of an oil derrick, under which are the words: NORTHLAND PETROLEUM CORP.
Anne Marie opens the hatchback and grabs a video camera.
Eric smiles as the wolf wobbles tentatively to his feet a trots unsteadily away.  Near the treeline the wolf turns, glances back at Eric and then disappears into the forest.

Anne Marie is taping the wolf's retreat.  Looking through the viewfinder, she crosses a gully between a pipeline piling and a rock formation.  Eric turns toward her and a glint of light in the debris at her feet catches his eye.
Anne Marie!  Stop!
She glances down.  Something metal is half-buried in the dead leaves and gravel.
(continuing) Don't move.

Eric runs over.  He pokes at the object with a stick.  Wi a SNAP, a steel leg trap chomps the stick in half.  Anne Marie jumps back.  Eric brushes the dead leaves on the ground behind her and she carefully backtracks out of the gully.
(continuing) Goddamn trappers!
He angrily rips the trap out of the ground, unearthing several others attached to one another by a long chain.
(continuing) Takes nerve, laying traplines on restricted land.
Eric slips the scope off the dart rifle and climbs up the pipeline on foot pegs to the top of an anchoring poINT.
Using the scope as a telescope, he scans up and down the Haul Road.
What are you doing?
He still might be around.  I saw fresh tire tracks coming in.
The road and the pipeline stretch toward either horizon, north and south.  In the distance, a jeep is parked on th Haul Road.  Near it, a Man climbs down into another shall ravine.
Eric hurries down the footpegs.
Man and a jeep, about a mile and a half down.
He jumps into the Scout.  Anne Marie stuffs her cameras i the hatchback.  As soon as she climbs in, Eric tears out.
It races along the dusty gravel road at 60 MPH.
Startled at the APPROACH of the Scout, the Trapper uproot his traps and runs out of the ravine.  He WHISTLES and another Trapper appears nearby.

They pile into their dilapidated, all-terrain jeep.  It's oddly well-equipped, however.  Bolted to the dashboard is expensive tape player and a beat-up radio beacon receiver with a round locating screen.  They zoom off.
Eric stomps on the gas.  The dust from the jeep obscures view but he's gaining on them anyway.  Anne Marie hangs o and squints her eyes against the choking dust.

The driver is LEMALLE (35), a tall, ugly, rawboned Canadi His entire outfit is made of animal hide.  He has long re hair, and a reptilian face usually twisted into a sadisti sneer.  While driving, he scans along the pipeline.
Where the fuck did you drop Corbett off?

In the passenger seat, MITCHELL (38), chews tobacco and looks grim.  He's a squat, flat-faced Okie, with curly matted hair and tired grey eyes.  He's dressed in a brown long coat and has a Colt .45 Peacemaker in a quick-draw holster strapped to his leg.  Despite his intimidating ai confrontation is not his style. He spots a figure up ahead, where the road crosses a mudd creek.
He's over there.

Turning sharply, the trappers' jeep splashes through the creek bed without slowing.  Bouncing, it comes down hard against the axle-deep bank at the creek's high water mark LeMalle tries to back out, but can't find traction in the mud. Eric stops the Scout thirty yards behind them.
Eric opens his door.  To Anne Marie:
Stay here.
Be careful -- there're two of them.
Eric reaches in the back seat and hands something to Anne Marie.
If I unzip my parka, stick this out the window.
Eric confidently approaches the jeep.

Then, a third trapper climbs from the creek.  He's got a line of traps slung around his neck and a world of experience on his face.  He's BEN CORBETT, a life-long huntsman, somewhere past forty, weathered beyond his year He has a feral nose, thick beard and dark, smart, hunter' eyes.  He wears a hooded cotton sweat shirt, cotton coveralls and vapor-barrier mountain boots.  On his belt a holster rig cradling a .44 magnum revolver. Eric slows down.  He didn't expect to face anyone as formidable as Corbett.
Emboldened by Corbett's presence, LeMalle reaches into th back seat and grabs his 6.5 by 55 Swedish military carbin
(to LeMalle) No shooting.  Let's see who's so interested in us.
Corbett has an incongruously affable voice.  He throws hi traps into the jeep, then strides closer toward Eric.
(to Corbett) Ain't worth it, Ben...
As Corbett comes closer, Eric realizes this might not've been a great idea.  Corbett squints his eyes and sniffs t air, as if by this he can gauge his opponent's mettle.
You got two counts against you -- trapping out of season and poaching on restricted land.
Can't be much of a crime, if all they got minding the area is a cocky kid.
I got your plate number, asshole. Maybe you feel like spending a few months in jail.
Corbett just smiles.
But LeMalle, rankled, sticks the carbine out the jeep window. Seeing the rifle pointed at him, Eric freezes, then slowl unzips his parka.
Ben?  Sure you don't want me to drop the fucker?
Corbett doesn't answer.  Then, his eyes narrow and he loo past Eric at the Scout.
The passenger in the Scout sticks what looks like another rifle out the window.
Eric quickly glances over his shoulder to make sure Anne Marie's backing him up.
You leave and don't come back, that's the end of it.
After a long moment, Corbett smiles again, then turns awa from Eric.  He motions LeMalle to the front of the jeep. Frustrated, LeMalle slams back the safety on the carbine throws it in the back seat.

Mitchell climbs into the jeep and starts the engine. LeMalle and Corbett rock the jeep back and forth in the r While pushing, Corbett rips the sole of his boot on a sha piece of granite.   He cusses and pushes harder.
Eric walks back to the Scout.  He feels the trappers' eye on his back, but forces himself not to hurry. The trappers free their vehicle.  Corbett gets in the driver's seat, and they take off.
Anne Marie's hands are shaking as she pulls the plastic tranquilizer rifle back in the window.
(unnerved) Great idea -- pointing a lousy dart gun at some nut with a high-powered hunting rifle.
Bastards took off, though, didn't they?
The trappers have left the flatlands of the Haul Road are Now their jeep climbs a pathway over the rolling foothill
Corbett broods while driving.  Mitchell looks out the window.  The silence makes LeMalle uncomfortable.
All this fuckin' land, and we're locked out.  Makes me puke.
Jawing about it won't change it.
Three hundred seventy-five million acres in this state.  I'm real tired of runnin' into people.
Then don't look to your left.

A brand-new Land Rover is parked on an alluvial fan in a bend in a small river.  Scattered about is an assortment expensive camping gear, beer cans, spent shells and other garbage. Three toy-macho, vacationing SPORTSMEN are guzzling beer BLASTING fish in the shallow river with 12-gauge shotguns They look up and glower suspiciously as the jeep slows an stops.
LeMalle grabs his carbine.
Leave it here.
Let's keep going.  We're only an hour from Devil's Cauldron.
(pats Mitchell's shoulder) Relax.  I just want to ask them how the hunting is.

Corbett gets out of the jeep.  He regards the Sportsmen, their shotguns and their mess with ill-concealed contempt The Sportsmen clutch their weapons and watch Corbett.  He walks around the camp, spotting a rubber-lined rucksack stuffed with dead ermine.  After a long, tense moment, Corbett smiles.
Looks like you've had some luck. Where's your guide?
We're on our own, if it's any of your damn business.
(re ermine) You did real good.
He crouches next to the dead animals and strokes the fur.
(to Corbett) No swinging shit.  They're over their goddamned limit.
(to Sportsmen) My friend is right.  Supposed to have a licensed guide when you're on this land, too.
Hey, we paid our fuckin' permit fees.
LeMalle amuses himself by pissing in their campfire.  No notices that in the b.g., quiet Sportsman #3 unzips his parka, exposing a .45 Peacemaker in a belt holster.
I were you, I'd drive right on outta here again.  Now.
(calmly) This was my roaming land, 'til the government took it over. Only Innuit can hunt here now, and tourists, like you.
Corbett swings the rucksack of carcasses onto the hood of the Land Rover.  Pissed, Sportsmen #1 and #2 step closer him.
(continuing) According to tribal law, hunters passing through the land of another tribe can only take game to survive.  They can eat the meat, but have to surrender the hides.
LeMalle pulls a hunting knife and holds up one of the ermine.
Want the meat?
Fuck you, dirtball.
Corbett chuckles and Mitchell spits.
LeMalle digs through the camping goodies in the back of t Land Rover, many still in their packages.  He helps himse to some sandwiches and a 12-pack of beer.
I say shoot 'em, bury 'em with their shiny new car.
(to LeMalle) If you're gonna take something, take it and let's go.
Corbett looks down to fasten the top of the rucksack.

Suddenly, Sportsman #3 reaches inside his parka and pulls the pistol.  He swings it toward LeMalle. LeMalle looks up when he hears the HAMMER cock. There is a deafeningly loud SHOT. Sportsman #3 falls down dead at LeMalle's feet. Off to one side, Corbett holds a huge, smoking .44 magnum six-shooter in his hand. Shotgun in hand, Sportsman #1 gauges his chances of blast Corbett.  Nil.  When Corbett turns to him, he lies the weapon down.  Sportsman #2 rushes to his friend. Looking bleak, Mitchell spits again.  Corbett crosses to LeMalle and knocks from his hands the things he wanted to steal.  Chastised, LeMalle smolders.  After a moment:
(to Sportsmen) Put him in your truck.  Smell of blood will attract the bears. (to trappers) Let's go.
As Corbett walks to the jeep, he's too angry to notice th he's stepped in a patch of mud under the Land Rover. Near the jeep, LeMalle stops and pulls them into a huddle
I don't believe in leavin' witnesses behind, Ben.
It was self defense.  Leave it at that.
You think those fucks will tell it that way?
(ending the argument) We'll get a head start before they go crying to the law.
Corbett turns and FIRES two rounds from his .44 into the engine of the Land Rover.  The Sportsmen stare and sputte
(continuing; to Sportsmen) You can pack out of here -- two, three days' hike along this river at most.  Weather should hold this early in the season.
Corbett and Mitchell get in their jeep.

isn't yet satisfied.  He walks back over to the Sportsmen kneeling beside their fallen friend, and crouches right beside them.  Intimidated, Sportsman #2 looks away, but LeMalle grabs his chin and turns his face back toward him
Think I'm pretty?  You better forget how we look, 'cause next time they won't keep me from killing you.  This land ain't quite civilized, you know...
He unsheathes his buck knife.  BELOW FRAME, he slices acr the forehead of the dead Sportsman, peels back his scalp cuts it loose, Indian-style.  The Sportsmen are stunned a sickened.
Corbett looks at Mitchell and wearily shakes his head.
At least he scalped the dead one.

Devil's Cauldron Hot Springs is a cluster of twenty tiny dwellings connected by an unpainted boardwalk.  The town squats, ugly and temporary-looking, in a dirt clearing fi miles north of the Arctic Circle.  Thirty miles east of t Pipeline, it's almost dead center of interior Alaska. At the edge of town is a gravel airstrip.  Mixed with the prospector-era sod-roof cabins are a few prefabricated houses.  The boon brought by men building the pipeline is long gone.  Now only a few itinerant loggers, natives and bush dwellers remain to fight boredom, each other and the depression of the oncoming winter. Enough steam escapes from the hot springs to perpetually blanket the valley with fog.  The spa is log-walled and horseshoe- shaped, with partitioned baths inside.  Facing

are a mud-walled fire bath, a wooden steam bath called a Maqi, six one-room cabins for let, and an unused dance ha LEO MEYERLING opens the tailgate of a Dodge truck with th Northland Petroleum logo and "District Supervisor" on the door.  Meyerling is short and bald with a completely disreputable face.  He staples a poster on a wall.  It ha picture of him on it, and:
for State Legislature VOTE FOR THE PEOPLE'S FRIEND!
Corbett and the other trappers drive past Meyerling and p their jeep as the sun disappears behind the foothills.

A handwritten public notice next to a schedule of church meetings reads: "Live each day so you can look every damn man in the eye and tell him to go to hell."  There is a p office in the corner with some combination boxes and a wicketless window. The trappers come in.  Corbett sits in a chair and pulls boots off.  One of his wool socks is wet.  He nods to the man sitting in the other chair, SAM WILDER.  Wilder is sh and tough, with a full head of crewcut grey hair and weather- ravaged face that makes him look older than his sixty years.
Hullo, Sam.  Slow day?
(wary) Ben...boys.  Yeah, real slow, and I'd like to keep it that way.
(conciliatory) Just passing through.

A chubby Inupiat (interior Eskimo), wearing thick glasses several heavy sweaters and battery-heated socks, fusses behind the counter.  He's EARL KENAI, owner of the hot springs spa and the general store. LeMalle chews on a handful of bear jerky.  Kenai stares a LeMalle until he begrudgingly pays for the jerky.  Corbet pulls on some sneakers and hands his boots to Kenai.
(continuing; re boot) Needs patching.
Twenty-five dollar.
(smiles) Sure have learned to worship the white man's god.
Kenai nods agreeably and holds his hand out.  Corbett pay him.  Meyerling comes in and posts some fliers on the corkboard.
I hope I can count on you gentlemen to vote for The People's Friend this November.
Share some of that oil company money in your pocket and you can.

Meyerling smiles like a toad, then slaps another poster o the wall.  LeMalle throws his knife and it STICKS in the poster between Meyerling's spread fingers.  Meyerling jum back and the trappers laugh.  Meyerling looks to Wilder f support.
(to Meyerling) One flier comes loose and I shoot you for littering.
(exiting; grudgeless) Have your fun... just remember The People's Friend come election day.
(shakes his head) Oil Company candidate running on that slogan makes about as much sense as a rat fucking a grapefruit.
Hard to work up an interest in politics, way we live.  You're the first people we've seen in two weeks.
(to Kenai) How about a quart of Jack Daniel's?
How about it is right.  Back in the primary this town was voted dry.
(to Corbett) Aw, shit.  Let's go.  Leave a note for Viking Bob, tell him to meet us in Cache.
Relax.  One more day without drink won't kill you.  Right, Sam?
I'm living proof of that sad fact.
Can we buy the Marshal some dinner?
No, I better stay at my post. Even without the hootch riling 'em up, you know how mean-spirited folks get when they smell winter coming.
An early STORM has blown in from the north, bringing whipping winds and freezing rain.

Corbett peers out the tiny window, frowning.  LeMalle cle his carbine while eating beans and bacon.  Mitchell hunch over a table.  He's making a scrimshaw -- delicately engraving, using homemade tools, on a palm-sized piece of whale bone.  He rubs his eyes and looks up at Corbett.
So much for the walking weather you predicted.
Had no choice... (pointedly, at LeMalle) ...Given the situation.
I know.  Least you didn't shoot all of them.
Fuck you, Mitchell.  Woulda been my ass if Ben didn't waste that prick.
(after a beat) Mitchell, look, it don't take three of us to wait for Viking Bob.
Mitchell glances at LeMalle, then at Corbett.
(continuing) Go ahead.  Take the jeep.  I'll come to Cache with Bob when he gets here.
Okay by me.  You're the one likes these hot springs so much.
Leave my traps.  We'll tag up, couple days.

The winds have died down.  The rain has turned to a light snow. A mobile arctic dwelling sits on a rise next to the Haul Road.  It's a double-unit weathertight cocoon of fibergla and aluminum, pulled by a diesel rig on oversized tires. The front module is 12 by 24, the rear 12 by 18. An extended-cab pickup pulls up and Sam Wilder gets out. The gravel-and-dirt Haul Road, paralleling the pipeline f 400 miles, is closed to the public.  An arriving vehicle, therefore, is news.  The front door of the dwelling opens Eric and Anne Marie come outside, delighted to see Wilder
I was making my rounds, saw your hangar wide open, plane getting rained on, so I closed it up.
Thanks.
(to Wilder) I bet you haven't had lunch.
(smiles) Bet you're right.  But I didn't come by to wangle a meal --
-- We appreciate the company. Anne Marie's getting cabin fever already.
Anne Marie shoots a look at Eric but doesn't disagree -- this is obviously an issue with them.  Wilder looks with amusement at the mobile dwelling.
What'd you say they call these spaceships?
Mobile Arctic Dwelling -- MAD.
I call it 'the Turtle,' as in carrying your home on your back.
Best thing is, Meyerling has to chase around to find us.
(laughs) The little creep hates it that Eric actually does what the company hired him to do.
Watch it with Meyerling.  Man's as mean and corrupt as they get. Cut his mother's throat if it'd get him a couple votes.
Looking past Wilder, Eric points out some smoke on the horizon.
Hey, Sam, look over there.  Black and white smoke.
Damn.  Likely that's an SOS. Have to pass on that lunch.
We'll go with you.

Everything seems peaceful enough.  The SOS fire (made fro burning green branches for white smoke and rubber for bla smoke) has burnt down to embers. Eric, Anne Marie and Wilder pull up in Wilder's pickup. The two Sportsmen sit in the front seat of the Land Rover but they don't react to the arrival of the rescuers.  In back seat, a reflective camping blanket covers a large ma Something is amiss.  Eric shoots a look of trepidation at Anne Marie as they get out of the pickup.   Wilder pulls door of the Land Rover open. A Sportsman slumps out onto the ground.  His eyes are ope and his tongue pokes out between his lips.  His skin is blue-white. (He looks, in fact, much like Eric's nightmar Startled, Eric steps back.  Anne Marie gasps with horror. Wilder unzips the Sportsman's light windbreaker and liste for a heartbeat.  Nothing.
Stupid goddamn greenhorns!  Froze to death.
It's not even winter!
They got wet in the rain.  Core body temperature dropped, got drowsy, probably didn't even know what was happening.
Eric stares at the dead Sportsmen.
(continuing) Question is why they sat here when the storm moved in.  Check their stuff while I sniff around.

Wilder tries the ignition.  The starter TURNS OVER, but t engine makes a horrendous GRINDING.  He walks to the fron of the vehicle.  Noticing the bullet holes in the grille, bends down for a closer look.
Eric opens the rear hatchback and digs through the plenti supplies.  Still in their packages are some matchbox-size ELT locating beacons.
They had Emergency Locater Transmitters, but didn't use them. (opens one up; shakes his head) Maybe because they didn't bring batteries.

Anne Marie opens the back door of the Land Rover.  She pu back the camping blanket... and uncovers the third Sportsman.  The torn red flesh on his head and his bugged-out eyes are a hideous sight. Anne Marie SCREAMS and stumbles away.
Eric runs over to her as she tries to catch her breath. Wilder looks at the third Sportsman and angrily kicks the side of the Land Rover.
I'm too old for this shit.
Any idea who could've done it?
Sourly, Wilder points to a patch of frozen mud under the vehicle.
A certain sonofabitch bastard -more-
WILDER (Cont'd) wearing a damaged mountain boot. Left a footprint clear as an autograph.
Wilder examines the Sportsman, finding the bullet hole in his chest.
(continuing) Even for Ben Corbett, this is nasty.  Man's got balls.  He was sitting in Devil's Cauldron when I left, calm as can be.
Thank God.  You can arrest him.
Not necessarily.  Corbett's awful hardbitten these days.
Wilder leans against the Land Rover, feeling tired.

(continuing) His old roaming area's all private reserve now.  Normally, long as he stays civil in my jurisdiction, I let him be. (beat) Won't be able to take him by my lonesome, though.  Nobody in town'll lift a finger on this.
Eric looks hard at the dead Sportsmen.
(quietly) I'll go into town with you.
Eric, leave it alone.  It's not your business.
(shakes his head) No way can he get away with this. I'll be back by tonight.
The town is quiet.

Corbett soaks in one of the huge wooden tubs with a pudgy Inupiat hooker, DIXIE. He looks up as Eric comes into the spa.  Eric holds Corbett's boots, which have been repaired.  Eric pauses w he sees Corbett.  There is a flash of recognition between them.
Ben Corbett?
Yep.  Afraid you have me at a disadvantage.
Kenai at the general store asked me to bring these.  Didn't expect we'd already met.
No big deal.  We just got off on the wrong foot.  What's your name?

Eric glances down at Corbett's duffel bag, which sits on floor next to Corbett's tub.  Corbett's magnum rests on t of it, well within reach.  Corbett notices Eric's interes in it.  He leans back and smiles.
Desmond.
New to the country, kid?
Six months.  Ecological study for Northland Oil.
Ecology.  Folks use that term for everything but what it means: who's eating who.

Putting his hand on Dixie's shoulder, Corbett stands and gets out of the tub.  His sinewy body, resembling a scarecrow made of steel cable, is covered with scars.  He wraps a towel around his waist and crosses to Eric.
(continuing) Now, why don't you get around to saying what you want.
Corbett grabs his boots from Eric and finds himself facin revolver, which Eric has been hiding inside one of the boots.
(continuing; smiling) You wouldn't shoot anyone...
But I would.
Wilder has come in the back way and stands behind Corbett with a 12-gauge shotgun.  He kicks Corbett's magnum out o reach.
All this for laying traps on private land?
You left a footprint at the Sportsmen's camp.  Only pretty sight there, Ben, 'cause the two men you didn't shoot and mutilate died of exposure.
Corbett shakes his head but remains implacable.
Christ if I shouldn't know better than to step in soft earth.  I've seen footprints in the tundra a hundred years old.
(to Eric) I got it from here.  Thanks.
(to Wilder) Sam, give Dixie here fifty bucks out of my kit, will you?
Eric comes outside.  Earl Kenai, overdressed for the weat in gloves, mukluks and a full-length sealskin coat, stand
shivering by a woodshed near the hot springs, hacksawing piece of meat from a frozen moose carcass.
Before white men came, my people lived in sod houses underground and laid our dead on the tundra. Now we live above ground and bury our dead, and we haven't been warm since.

Wilder comes out of the spa with his shotgun and Corbett' duffel bag cradled in his arm.  Handcuffed, Corbett walks front of him. Kenai looks down to avoid eye contact with Corbett as he goes by.  Corbett stops next to Eric and smiles.
Nice bluff the other day with the tranquilizer gun out your jeep window.  See you again, maybe.
(unintimidated) Yeah.  Maybe so.

as he leads Corbett along the boardwalk to the other end town.  They approach a prefab house perched on skids unde tall antenna tower.  Mounted above the shack, a DC wind charger turbine spins lazily in the faint breeze.  From within the cabin comes an anomalous SOUND -- MTV.  Wilder KNOCKS on the door. ARTHUR NEFF, a pasty-white, 45-year-old ex-Texan, pulls t door open.  His customary grin fades when he sees Corbett
Wilder pushes Corbett inside past Neff.
I need to call Fairbanks.
Neff just stares at Corbett.
(continuing) Neff!  Dial it up.  State police.
With a "what can I do but oblige?" look to Corbett, Neff sits in front of the RCA Alascom radio telephone and dial
(on phone) Fairbanks Alascom?  Patch me through to the State Police.
After a moment, he hands the receiver to Wilder.  Wilder takes it, keeping one eye and the shotgun on Corbett.
(on phone) This is Sam Wilder, Marshal in Devil's Cauldron.  Had some killings here.  I got a suspect; be real nice if someone came and took him off my hands.
(thru phone) On a good day I couldn't spare a crosswalk guard.  But now, no way.  Folks're batshit with the weather turning sour.  Bring him in yourself.
(on phone) Next plane's not coming 'til next Monday.
(thru phone) Sit your suspect out in the cold. He'll keep.
(on phone) This man's friends ain't gonna look favorably on his incarceration.
(thru phone; Mr. Glib) So shoot him.  Won't have to feed him that way --
Angry, Wilder slams the receiver down.

In one room, there is a wood-burning cookstove and an Ash heat stove, a table, a bunk and a small window.  Behind a cloth partition is an eight by six holding cell.  The fra of an iron-bar door is securely cemented to the log walls Wilder comes in with Corbett and locks him in the cell.
Mind if I get some stuff from my kit?
Wilder does mind.  He locks the duffel bag and Corbett's in his desk drawer.
(continuing) Sam, listen -- I shot to defend my man.  Other guy drew first.
If that was all, fine.  But carving him up, stranding the others, that's too fucking much. Is everything that walks, crawls, flies or swims fair game to you?
(softly) I'll get loose before that plane comes.
Don't try me.  I'll kill you if it comes to it.
As Eric walks into Kenai's general store, Neff hurries ov
Mr. Desmond! (grins; sticks his hand out) Arthur Neff.  Area rep for the Federal Assistance Plan.  Tell the boys in DC to keep those goodies coming.
Sure.
Snowplow, generator, TV dish... hell, we get the goddamn Playboy Channel!  Here, this is for you.
He hands Eric a piece of styrofoam shaped like a commode seat.
(continuing) Warm to forty below.  Remember, anything you want, you ask Arthur Neff.
The storm has passed.   A faint CHUGGING emanates from th small orange generator trailer behind the Turtle.  Eric pulls up and parks the Scout.

Nylon storage netting along the ceiling holds Eric's research equipment and Anne Marie's photographic supplies In one corner of the Turtle are several of her black and white prints.  All are of man-made objects whose presence juxtaposed with the natural surroundings. Relieved he's home in one piece, Anne Marie meets Eric at the door and kisses him.  Carrying a brown-paper-wrapped package, Eric follows her into the kitchen, where she's preparing dinner.
Did you catch Corbett?
Sure did.  He was one of the trappers we rousted from the Haul Road.
Was there any trouble?
He was sitting in a hot tub with a hooker.
Going after killers isn't the same as chasing poachers, Eric.
(grins) Can't help myself.  Corbett's type always pisses me off. (hands her the package) Oh, I found this at the post office.  Had your name on it.
Perplexed, she looks at the return address -- Bloomingdale's.  Delighted, she tears it open.  Inside is pretty, elegant dress.  Anne Marie kisses him.
Oh, sweetheart.  It's beautiful!
You were looking at it in the catalog.  Don't know where you can wear it...
I'll wear it for you.  And I can wear it when we go home.  We won't be here forever.
(frowning) You make it sound like a prison sentence.
That's not what I meant.
It's exactly what you meant.
Look, why get into this again. As long as it's working, let's leave it alone.  It's been nice so far.  We're together --
-- Permanently?

(sighs) Do I want to be with you permanently?  Yes, I think I do. But be with what you do and the way you live?  That I don't know. C'mon, Eric, until I met you, coming back to Alaska was totally out of the question for me.  But I'm here.  I'm getting great pictures, and I'm having fun. (slips her arms around him) I love you. (kisses him) So shut up and let's eat.

An old primer-grey station wagon rattles into town and parks.  With an unlit cheroot stuck in his mouth, "VIKING BOB CORBETT gets out and stretches.  He's 38, six-foot-si with sandy hair, beard, ruddy skin, and his brother's dar eyes. He looks around for some sign of life.  He spots Neff tending one of the windmills and walks over to him.
I'm looking for some trappers. Ben Corbett, Mitchell, LeMalle. Seen 'em?
Yesterday.  Said they were going to Cache.  They were thirsty, but we were voted dry.
Shit.
As Viking Bob walks back to his station wagon, he notices Kenai poking around in front of Wilder's cabin.

Illuminated by a bare bulb is Wilder's typical bush-count front yard.  Piled are five cords of wood, boxes, tarps, stove parts, saw horses, 55-gallon drums, dismantled snow machines, wash tubs, tires, etc. Bunching his collar around his neck, Kenai shivers and so through Corbett's traps.
Viking Bob ambles over to Kenai.
These yours?
Gonna make an offer.  Man who owns them won't need them where he's going.
Wilder peers out the window and sees Viking Bob, then tur to Corbett.
Back against the bars.  Now.

Wilder handcuffs Corbett's hands to the cell door bars, t quickly wraps a piece of duct tape across Corbett's face, covering his mouth. Stuffing a .357 magnum in his belt, Wilder, coatless, sli outside. As soon as he's out the door, Corbett cranes his neck and painfully tries to pry the tape off his face with the cor of the door hinge.
The look on Wilder's face tells Kenai to shut up.  Viking Bob realizes something's up.
Your brother and the boys left me some traps to sell for them. They're gone --
-- To Cache.  So I heard.  Ben never said nothing to me about selling his gear.
Corbett gets the tape partially off his mouth.  He pries of his boots off and kicks it through a window.
Bob!  They got me on a murder charge!
Wilder pulls his .357 out.
Sorry, Bob.  I'll have to keep you here 'til I ship him south.

Viking Bob responds by flinging a heavy trap at Wilder, t punching him in the gut.  Wilder sprawls among the junk, dropping his revolver.  Kenai freezes, not about to take sides. Before Viking Bob can come at him again, Wilder grabs for his .357. Viking Bob jumps back and bolts for his car.
He dives into his station wagon and starts it up.  As he drives past, Wilder POPS off a few rounds, but Viking Bob keeps going.
Kenai helps Wilder up.  Pissed, Wilder shoves him against the cabin.
(continuing) You stupid, greedy, loudmouth sonofabitch!  He'll have the others here in a few hours.  You fucked me up, now you're gonna help me move him.
(shakes head) Forget it, Sam.  I never work for free.

Anne Marie sits on the floor, editing one of her VIDEOTAP On the monitor, it SHOWS footage of the traps under the pipeline piling.  Eric comes out of the back module holdi two ELT pendants.  He glances over at the monitor and nod approvingly.
I still can't believe I'm being financed by an oil company. Especially when they get a look at these pictures.  Technology in the wilderness; not too pretty. (re ELTs) What's that?
I thought I should check our emergency transmitters.
Eric activates the ELT's.  They emit an SOS pattern of ra waves -- three short, three long and three short.  This i visible as rhythmic INTERFERENCE on Anne Marie's video MONITOR.
(continuing) Avalanche season is coming.
Winter.  Two straight months of night -- we may never get out of bed. (kisses him) Which would suit me fine.
Prolonged darkness makes people crazy.
Not me.  I'm equipped.
She turns on a small S-VHS video camera and snaps off the room lights.
(continuing) Allow me to give you a practical demonstration of low-light infrared photography...
She does so by seductively undressing for the camera.  Sh SEEN on the MONITOR, illuminated by the "light" from the stove.  Eric appreciates the show.  He crawls toward her.
(continuing) High-tech in the wilderness. Gets me excited, too.
Come here...
Laughing, he wrestles her to the rug.

There is a full moon and a clear night sky.  Viking Bob's station wagon is parked out of sight.  He sits inside, waiting. He hears an ENGINE starting in the distance.  Sitting up, grabs some binoculars.
Wilder's extended cab truck pulls out, heading west.
In the bright moonlight, two people are seen in Wilder's truck as it speeds along a dirt road. Viking Bob follows at a discreet distance, headlights off

Viking Bob turns and takes the literal high road -- a nar trail above the roadway that Wilder's truck is on. He zooms ahead and gets in front of his quarry, then drop back down onto the road and waits in ambush. As Wilder's truck approaches, Viking Bob turns on his bri lights and crouches behind his car door with a shotgun. Wilder's truck screeches to a stop.
Kenai gets out with his hands up. Viking Bob slowly approaches Wilder's truck.
Ben?
No answer.  Viking Bob looks in the cab.  Kenai's passeng is Dixie, the Inupiat hooker.  Viking Bob grabs Kenai and pushes the barrel of the shotgun hard against his cheek.
(continuing) Where's Ben Corbett?
I have no argument with you, Bob. Wilder said I could keep his truck if I drove it ten miles away from town.
Where did they go?
He didn't say, but I would guess the opposite way from here.
Viking Bob shoves Kenai against the truck, then punches h for good measure.  Cussing, he runs back to his station wagon and drives off.
Eric and Anne Marie are asleep.  Eric starts awake at the sound of a high-pitched vehicle HORN and an approaching ENGINE.
Eric pulls the door open.  Wilder is untying Corbett from the snowmobile.
I got an emergency on my hands.
Corbett smiles at Eric as he walks inside.

Eric, Wilder and Corbett sit in the front module.  Anne Marie, nervous, wearing a down robe, serves coffee.  She stares at Corbett, trying to reconcile his quiet demeanor with what she saw that afternoon.  Corbett smiles at Eric
(to Eric) ...You give us a ride in the Cessna you got hangared at the pumping station, we'll be in Fairbanks in a few hours.
That's what we should've done in the first place.
I could've sat tight for the transport, 'til Bob came poking around.
(to Wilder; re Anne Marie) A lot to ask, dragging him away from such a good-looking girl --
(irritated) -- To take you to jail?  It'll be my pleasure.
(to Eric) You better get some sleep.
Good idea.  Flying over mountains can give you some nasty surprises.  Go too low, one of the clouds might have a big rock inside it.
(hard) I'll get you there all right.
Eric takes Anne Marie to the rear module, leaving Wilder with his prisoner.

A bottle of Eric's Scotch sits almost empty on the table beside Wilder.  Wilder dozes in a chair facing Corbett. Corbett is awake.  He contorts his body to bring his handcuff chain under his feet and get his hands in front him.  He eyes Wilder's .357.  It's in a lefty Sam Browne holster.  No way to take it without waking Wilder. Corbett stands and inches toward the door.  As he pulls i open, the insulation makes enough NOISE to stir Wilder. Wilder gets up and pushes Corbett back into his chair.
Goddammit, I don't need this aggravation.  I'll shoot you, Ben.  Bank on it.
I don't want to hurt you, Sam.
I'm not too old to knock the snot out of you!
Nothing personal.

Wilder's mind clears enough to realize that Corbett's han are in front of him.  He reaches for his .357.  Corbett butts into Wilder's midsection with his head.  Amazingly, Wilder stays on his feet. Corbett hurries back to the door.  Wilder lunges, bull-determined to hold onto him.  Corbett smashes Wilder across the face with his clenched hands.  Wilder goes dow hard, hitting his head on the table, and stays there. Corbett instinctively kneels to see if Wilder is still breathing.  But then, hearing MOVEMENT in the rear module Corbett flees.
Eric is pulling on his pants.

Eric rushes in.  The outside door is open and Wilder lies the floor.   His holster is empty.  Anne Marie comes in a crosses to Wilder. Eric pulls a floor trap door open and digs through the company-issue equipment, coming up with a huge Remington bolt-action bear rifle.  Unfamiliar with weapons, Eric te open a box of shells and fumbles to load the rifle.
Corbett is trying to start Eric's Scout. Eric fires a loud warning SHOT from the Turtle doorway.
You want to try that handgun against this rifle, go ahead.

Corbett sits in the Scout for a long moment, weighing his odds.  He takes his hands off the steering wheel... Eric SHOOTS again, this time SMASHING the side-view mirro and window next to Corbett's head. Still handcuffed, Corbett gets out of the Scout.  Holding the .357 gingerly by the butt, he puts it on the hood of Scout.
Some day you might have to face me without a gun.
Eric leads Corbett in.  Anne Marie is cradling Wilder's head. She's crying.  Eric looks at Wilder.  There is bloo coming from his ear and he's fading fast.
(thickly) Fetch him back? (Eric nods) Don't let him walk...
Eric nods again.  Wilder holds his gaze on Eric, then sim stops breathing.
Eric is stunned.  Quietly, Corbett sits down.  Clutching rifle, Eric sits on the floor and glares at Corbett.
(softly) Does he have people?
(after a beat) A daughter in Oregon.
Send him down to her.  There's money in my duffel bag, back at his cabin.
Corbett's benign attitude is chilling.
I better call in.
He turns the shortwave radio on.  It SPARKS and burns out The remainder of the liquor has been poured inside it.
(continuing) Thought of everything, huh?
Surviving is what I know --
-- Killing is what you know. (to Anne Marie) Pack some food while I prep for the flight. (off her look) I'm sure not gonna let him go.
Covering Corbett with the rifle, Eric handcuffs him to th sturdy metal bracket of a wall unit.

Viking Bob approaches in his station wagon on a narrow di road.  The huge night sky all but smothers the weak light from the town up ahead. Cache seems a mistake -- a jumble of unpainted buildings the middle of a big nothing, twenty miles north of the Arctic Circle.  Still, it's more animated than Devil's Cauldron.  There are a hundred permanent residents, sever taverns and a three-store, fly-in shopping center.

Even though it's the middle of the night, people roam the streets, drinking and socializing.  With only a couple fe of snow on the ground, this is still summertime.  Under storefront awnings, drunken INDIANS sleep on the concrete Viking Bob cruises the main drag, looking for the other trappers.  He spots their jeep in front of a dangerous-looking saloon called the "Bear Sign Inn."
as he parks and gets out of his station wagon.  He hears familiar VOICE around the side of the building.
C'mon, girl, talk to me, negotiate with me...
Drunk, LeMalle stands in an alley with a bored, acne-scar Oriental PROSTITUTE.  He weaves and leers, his hand stuck inside her blouse.
LeMalle.  We got a problem. Where's Mitchell?
Goddamn!  Viking Bob!  Mitchell's inside, boring bastard...
Grumbling, Viking Bob separates LeMalle from the Prostitu and drags him by the collar out of the alley.

Meyerling's campaign posters cover the walls.  Many have been pulled down and muddied underfoot by the drunken cro In a booth covered with grafitti, Mitchell squints and wo on his scrimshaw.  LeMalle, somewhat sober, eats a plate muktuk -- whale blubber.  Viking Bob pours him more coffe
(to Viking Bob) ...Ben never sent a signal.
Musta never got a chance to -more-
VIKING BOB (Cont'd) activate.  Wilder's aiming to take him to Fairbanks, we can count on that much.
Meaning he'll need a plane.
Closest planes for hire are here in Cache.
Hang on... (to LeMalle) Remember that Cessna we saw at the pumping station on the Haul Road?  Belongs to the guy they got patrolling the pipeline.
There you go.  Wilder's always chummy with the fuckin' Bambi-lovers.
It's a long shot.
You got a better idea?
Wisps of light cut across the cold blue sky. Eric comes out of the Turtle, leaving the front door ajar He throws a knapsack of supplies into the back of the Sco
Corbett's right hand is still handcuffed to the wall unit Terrified about being alone with Corbett, Anne Marie cautiously puts a cup of coffee in front of him.
How long have you been up north?
(after a beat) Six months.
Can't be.  Too keen a sense of this place in your pictures.
Six months this time.  I was born in the Aleutians.
Your people Alaskan?
Anne Marie doesn't want to talk to a killer, but Corbett so soft-spoken and charming that she answers despite herself.
My dad was a Navy doctor.
Knew you had no native blood, even with your dark hair.  Blue eyes give you away.  My wife had blue eyes.
Had?
She's dead.
Oh.

Had some good years.  Met her in '66.  She showed up one day in Coldfoot.  No one knew her.  One Sunday morning, she marched into a bar and announced she was available as a wife to the highest bidder.  Didn't work out in three months, she'd return the money and leave, no hard feelings. (off Anne Marie's amazed look) My bid was eight thousand dollars.  Beautiful girl.
How did she..?
I was gone, in September, laying traplines.  She went to our cache for some meat.  Got mauled by a bear.  Tore open her skull. -more-
CORBETT (Cont'd) Might've lived if she got help, but the exposed part of her brain froze.
Anne Marie shudders.  Smiling good-naturedly, Corbett loo around, spotting the package Anne Marie's new dress came
(continuing) What about you -- why come back? Classy girl like you seems more suited to the finer things.

That's why I left, moved to Washington.  When I met Eric I was doing day shoots -- products and fashion, mostly.  Pretty dull.  Eric was teaching college, and then he got the job with Northland Oil.  We wanted to stay together, so we talked them into funding some wilderness photography... and here I am.
As she's talking, the Turtle ROCKS slightly.  She looks o the tiny window.
Eric is putting Wilder's body inside an enclosed storage compartment built flush into the side of the Turtle.
Horrified, Anne Marie turns away.
You should know something.
I don't want to talk any more.

Wasn't my intention to hurt Wilder.  I'm telling you the truth.  I liked the man.  I only meant to get loose... to survive. Your cheechako boyfriend better understand that. (beat) Listen, I've got some money put away --
-- Don't ever think you can buy Eric off, Mr. Corbett --
-- Cheechako?
Eric comes in, none too thrilled about Anne Marie chattin with Corbett.
(translating) Outsider.
He carefully stuffs Wilder's magnum in his belt and ignor Anne Marie's disparaging look as he does.
(to Corbett) Let's go.
Wait a second.
Anne Marie leads Eric out of earshot from Corbett.  Eric keeps a cautious eye on him.
Maybe you should drive him into Devil's Cauldron, let them decide what to do with him.
(reassuringly) Fairbanks is a three-hour flight. I'll be back by dinnertime.
Realizing he's determined, she sighs and kisses him.
(continuing) Be careful, okay?
That's my line.
Eric and Corbett drive toward the deserted pumping statio They cross over a prefabricated steel portal bridge spann a fast-running creek.
The wind whips through the shot-out wing window.  Corbett handcuffs are lashed to the seat frame with sturdy nylon rope.
The pumping station consists of three corrugated steel buildings.  The largest is an airplane hangar. Just beyond the hangar is a narrow blacktop landing strip running parallel to the Haul Road.
Eric pulls up to the hangar.  Suddenly, LeMalle steps out from behind the building.
LeMalle recognizes the International Scout.  He swings hi rifle up to stop it. Eric slams it in reverse and SCREECHES back around the hangar.
Aim for the tires!
LeMalle FIRES as the Scout rounds the corner.  He hits a fender, doing no damage.  Angry, he runs after the vehicl
Eric slams on the brakes and turns the Scout around.
Let me out and keep going.  They catch us, they'll kill you.
Eric doesn't need any convincing of that.  He tears out.
Mitchell runs out in front of them and BLASTS the front o the Scout with his .45 Peacemaker.  Steam HISSES out of t radiator.  Eric floors it and races past Mitchell, almost hitting him.
Mitchell and LeMalle SHOOT at the retreating vehicle.  On of the Scout's back tires gets blown out.
Eric slows, shifts into four-wheel drive and continues, driving on the rim.
Chewing an unlit cheroot, Viking Bob pulls up next to Mitchell and LeMalle in the trappers' jeep.  They pile in
Eric backtracks as fast as possible in the crippled vehic
As the Scout heads for the Feldspar Creek bridge, it disappears from sight over a hill.
Viking Bob zooms over Feldspar Creek.  They come over the rise, but the Scout still can't be seen ahead of them.

The Scout sits idling in a depression near the creek bed, below the Haul Road.  Above, the trappers speed past with noticing. After giving the trappers time to get around the next ben Eric drives the Scout up the embankment and crosses back over the bridge.
Eric stops the vehicle.  He grabs a five-gallon gas can a a piece of cloth from the back.

The prefab bridge is the transportable type used by the A Corps of Engineers, left over from the building of the pipeline.  Eric stuffs the gas can between the abutment a the honeycombed underside of the bridge.  He puts the rag inside the spout of the can, lights it with a match and r like hell back to the Scout.
The trappers realize their quarry is missing.  Viking Bob slams on the brakes and looks around.
Eric speeds away.
They'll still catch us.  All you're doing is pissing them off.
The gasoline can EXPLODES, tearing the bridge couplings a from the concrete abutment.
The trappers see the explosion behind them.  They turn around and head toward it.

Eric parks the Scout sideways to block the way to the airstrip. With the magnum at the ready, Eric cuts Corbett's handcuf loose from the seat and hurries him toward the hangar. The leeward side of the structure is a huge metal door on rollers.  Eric unlocks it and rolls it back.  Inside is a Cessna 182, dusted with snow and ice blown through the cracks by crosswinds.  Eric brushes the windshield with h sleeve.
The trappers pull up and find the far side of the bridge burning and disconnected from the creek bank.
Eric helps Corbett into the cockpit, then secures his handcuffs to the frame of the seat with more nylon rope.
Viking Bob assesses the damage to the bridge.  Loose from the abutments, it wobbles like a diving board.  Below, th water is too deep and fast-moving to be traversable.
Eric tries to turn the ENGINE over.  The starter is slugg from cold and lack of use.
Viking Bob looks at the others, bursting with frustration He climbs into the driver's seat.
Get in.  We can jump it.

They hop in.  He SCREECHES backwards to get a running sta REVS the engine, pops the clutch, and tears toward the bridge. As they reach the midpoint of the bridge it begins to buc under them.  With a sickening WRENCHING, the crossbar supports crumple. The jeep flies through the still-burning gasoline, become airborne, and SCRAPES to a rude stop on the edge of the pavement on the other side, the back wheels dangling in space. LeMalle and Mitchell gingerly get out and push the ass en of the jeep onto solid earth.
Eric finally STARTS the plane and taxis out onto the land strip.
The trappers drive up to where the Scout blocks their pat They pile out of their jeep and run toward the landing strip.
It picks up speed and takes off.
Below, the trappers watch the plane zoom over their heads LeMalle points his carbine at it, but Viking Bob pushes t rifle down.
Corbett scowls as he sees the trappers helpless below him
Viking Bob watches, wide-eyed with fury.  Mitchell spits. LeMalle punches the wall.  Then he turns and repeatedly BLASTS the Scout, parked nearby, with his carbine.
Eric's knapsack, an emergency kit and several five-gallon cans of aviation fuel are tucked behind the seats.
How the hell were they smart enough to find us?
Smart?  Sure.  That's why I'm sitting in this plane and they're down there blowing me kisses.
Eric retracts the landing gear and banks toward the southwest.  Corbett notices that Eric seems a little unsu of the controls.
(continuing) Been driving long?
I needed a pilot's license to take the job here, so I got one in six weeks.
That makes the flight more interesting.

Eric ignores the jibe.  He stays at 2,000 feet, making th landscape all the more immediate. Corbett stares out the window and broods.  He spots an op snow-covered area where some dark blotches mar the whiteness.

(continuing) See the blood?  Pack of wolves took down a moose.  Greedy, gut-ripping sons of bitches.  I'd kill the last wolf on earth, right in front of the President of the U.S.  Stinking, cowardly predator, the wolf.
Sounds like professional jealousy.

Hunting and trapping was a damn fine life. (beat) Me and Mitchell, Bob and LeMalle, we were teams.  I'd always go with Mitchell.  Good man, Mitchell.  I'd let Bob worry about goddamn LeMalle.  We'd hire a plane in October.  On the way to a dirt airstrip somewhere, we'd drop supplies.  We'd land, tell the pilot to come back for us a few days before Christmas.
While talking in an even tone, Corbett intently studies t instrument panel and scans the landscape below.
The idea was to get to the supplies before the bears did. Along the route we'd set our traps.  Made our year's living in three months.
Corbett spots a flat plateau farther in the mountains, ab the tree line.
(continuing) Lot of times we didn't even have a landing strip.  We'd set down on a plateau, like that one there.  Yeah, that one's easy; you could glide right in...

Suddenly, he turns in the seat and pins Eric against the door with his left foot. The plane flies erratically.  With his right foot, Corbet kicks the fuel jettison lever on the instrument panel, jamming it on.
The lever, used to empty the fuel tanks in case of emergency, does so with great expediency.  All the gas is instantly discharged.

Corbett releases Eric and calmly sits back up in his seat Eric rubs his neck, incredulous.  Corbett's move was too fast and too outrageous.  In a moment, the engine SPUTTER to a stop.  Eric struggles to hold the stick steady and glide the plane down to the plateau Corbett pointed out.
Hope you got your money's worth on those lessons.

There's an even chance of hitting a mountain instead of t plateau.  Eric pushes the Cessna's nose down.  The platea comes up fast. The plane drops lower and lower, pitching and yawing in t wind. It CRASH LANDS, its metal underbelly SCREECHING as it hit the jagged granite under the snow.  It stops suddenly, flipping tail over nose.

It rests upside down in the snow.  The men are dazed. Behind Eric, one of the extra fuel cans, now hanging upsi down, leaks gas.  In front of him, the engine is ON FIRE. Eric undoes his seat belt and rights himself, but his leg gets caught in the tangled belt.  He pulls out a Swiss Ar knife and cuts the rope binding Corbett's handcuffs to th seat.  Corbett pushes the passenger door open.  Panicking Eric tries to pull loose of his seat belt, painfully wrenching his ankle.

Corbett rolls out into the snow.  With no time to grab hi supplies, Eric clambers from the wreckage.  He and Corbet crawl/roll down the incline of the plateau, away from the plane. A moment later the leaking gas reaches the burning engine and the Cessna EXPLODES.
Eric tries to stand.  He cries out and falls into the powdery snow, clutching at his ankle.
Corbett realizes Eric is at a disadvantage.  But before h can bolt, Eric grabs for the .357 magnum under his coat. lies on the snow, gasping, pointing the gun at Corbett's midsection.
Stay put!
You got the belly to look me in the eye and pull the trigger?
Eric cocks the gun's hammer with his thumb.
Be no different than shooting a rabid dog.
The men face off for a tense moment. Corbett smiles and zips up his jacket, dispelling the tension.  Letting the hammer down, Eric looks back at the burning plane.
(continuing) Next time you want to kill yourself, don't include me.
I took the odds on getting down in one piece, and I made it.  Now we're in my territory.
With light clothing and no supplies, this is nobody's territory.
You sound like the tourists. Know-it-alls who read about survival in a magazine.  Fuck you.  You won't make it off this mountain.
Corbett drops his facade of conviviality.  Eric is too an to be intimidated.  He takes the scarf from around his ne and wraps his ankle with it.
Let's go.
(re Eric's ankle) I'm not gonna carry you out of here.
That's right.  You're not.
Look, take these cuffs off.  We need to work together.
Forget it.
Eric holds his wristwatch up, points the hour hand at the sun, counts forward to noon, and, accordingly, makes an approximation of their direction.
(continuing) Last time I checked the flight plan, we were forty miles northeast of Devil's Cauldron. Southwest is that way.  No sense waiting for a goddamn taxi.

Grimacing with pain, he gets up.  Clutching the magnum, h shoves Corbett in front of him and starts walking.  Corbe frowns -- it's tough to trudge through the snow with his arms cuffed tightly behind his back. Eric looks around and tries not to let his emotions regis on his face.  They wouldn't be farther from the rest of humanity on another planet.  Smelling fear on Eric, Corbe enjoys the view.  And waits.

The Endicott range is full of jagged peaks, icy streams a gnarled tundra valleys.  Squinting in the glare of the sn Eric and Corbett trek through the grandiose Gates of the Arctic area.  The smoldering plane wreckage is a hard-won snow-covered mile behind them. Intricate patterns of fragmented rock, strips of scruffy tundra and bedrock outcrops produce lonely, foreboding mosaics upon the landscape.  The air is still.  The silen is itself a disconcerting presence.  Ten miles ahead and thousand feet lower, the forest begins.  But here, on the rock face of the mountains, Eric and Corbett might as wel be in a desert.
It'll be interesting, trying to build a fire without any wood.
Welcome to the environment, Mr. Ecology.  Out here, one mistake is all you get.
Determined and dour, Eric pushes on.
(continuing) Why in hell you care enough about me to die taking me in?
I don't plan on dying.
It's all academic.  The sheer magnitude of the surroundin makes them feel they're the only people in the world.

The sun drops behind the mountains.  A wind whips up, chilling the men through their clothing.  Eric tries not shiver.  He spies a small rock formation with a granite elbow protruding from it, making an enclosed triangle of solid rock.
We'll stop here, dig out a snow shelter.
Snow shelter.  Okay.  You dig. I'll have a little sit-down.
Corbett sits on his haunches and smiles while Eric digs n the rocks.  Although he knows Corbett is testing his ever move, Eric refuses to let his patronizing air get to him.
(continuing) Even in the drifts, this snow's too powdery to make a shelter. When you're done jerking around, reach down the back of my coat.
Eric approaches him suspiciously.  He puts his hand down through Corbett's collar.  Something is stowed inside a homemade flap in the lining of his coat.  Eric pulls out
folded nylon tarp with twine threaded through corner eyeholes.  He shakes the eight by eight orange tarp open.
Eric and Corbett have stretched the tarp out tent-style n to the granite rock formation, making a minimal but functional refuge from the cold night.
The men huddle inside the tarp.  Eric keeps a wary eye on Corbett -- at all times he treats him like a rattlesnake. Eric unwraps his ankle and rubs it.  It's swollen to the size of a softball.
Still quite a hike to Devil's Cauldron. (beat) Days.  A long stretch to go without sleep, my friend.  You can hide behind that pistol for now, but take your eyes off me long enough to sneeze --
-- Turn around.
While poking the .357 in Corbett's ribs, Eric one-handedl unlocks Corbett's right manacle, pulls his arm through th granite elbow, then locks it back up again.  He's learnin

Eric is hurrying along the pipeline in his business suit, following the predator's paw prints in the snow.  He peer ahead and his prey becomes visible.  But it isn't a wolf, it's Corbett.  His hands and face are covered in blood.
The sun peeks over the mountain tops, drenching them with light and color.

The light hits Eric's eyes.  He bolts awake from a fitful sleep.  Corbett sits, already awake, looking like he'd uproot the rock to which he's chained if he could.  He wa for an opportunity -- any opportunity -- with the patienc of a vulture.

Eric and Corbett trudge up to the bank of a frozen stream bisecting their path.  It's simple -- to continue, they h to cross it.  Corbett takes in the scenery, in no particu hurry.  Frustrated, but making dead sure he's always got drop on Corbett,  Eric puts a tentative foot on the ice.
Ice is too thin -- you can see the water moving underneath.
We're not sitting here 'til November.  There's a cargo plane coming to Devil's Cauldron in four days, and I'm putting you on it.
We get wet, we freeze to death in a couple hours.
I've been on ice like this when I was a kid, skating.  Spread your weight, keep moving.  Go on.
Corbett is not about to be outdone in the guts department someone with a Master's Degree.
(gestures 'you first') Be my guest.
(points .357) I'm right behind you.
Frowning, Corbett tentatively steps onto the ice and inch across the fifteen feet to the other bank.
He turns and, indeed, Eric is right behind him.
Wait 'til I'm across!

Eric doesn't want to be too far from his prisoner.  He ke coming.  The ice GROANS and HISSES under their weight. Corbett is three feet from solid ground.  He drops to his knees, then stomach, and rolls like a log the rest of the way. Eric splays out on the ice and crabwalks across.  The ice makes an ominous CRACKING and water begins to seep throug air holes. Standing, Corbett weighs his chances of bolting from Eric Eric crawls doubletime.  He makes it onto solid ground ju as the ice under him breaks off in a big, thin, clear pla
Eric sits on some rocks.  Corbett glares it him.
Most dangerous thing in the world: A regular Joe, in over his head.  You trying to prove how tough you are for me, or for yourself?
It wasn't my idea to crash the plane.
Let's camp.  There's grayling under this ice. I'll snare some for dinner.
(standing) We've got another two hours of daylight.
Pushing it is flat wrong.  All you prove is your ignorance about breaking trail.
Eric is not convinced.   Grumbling, Corbett gets up and takes the lead as they continue southward.
Trying to keep busy, Anne Marie develops some prints in t darkroom she's made from the front bathroom.  She glances her watch and sighs, her mind on Eric's overdue return.
Anne Marie comes out of the darkroom and hangs the prints to dry.  Outside, (OS), a car HORN blares a couple of tim Grinning, she runs to the door.

Meyerling's Dodge truck pulls up.  Anne Marie comes outsi Her smile wilts when she sees it's not Eric.  As Meyerlin climbs the embankment to the Turtle, he glances at Wilder snowmobile parked alongside the Turtle.
I've been trying to raise you on the shortwave for two days.
He pushes past Anne Marie and goes into the Turtle.
Have you talked to Eric?
I have not, but I very much want to.  What do you know about the trouble in Devil's Cauldron?
I was hoping you had some news --

-- Get this straight: I'm the District Supervisor.  Whatever you do reflects on me.  It wasn't my idea to bring you people up here, but I'm stuck with you. You are absolutely not to involve yourself in any local disputes. Whichever side you take, you alienate the other.  Mr. Corbett is quite well-known in this region.  People admire him --
-- Corbett's a killer.
I don't care if Ben Corbett makes meatloaf out of nuns and babies, he's not your concern. Understood?
Anne Marie just glares at him.  Meyerling examines the damaged shortwave.
(continuing) What happened here?
The radio's on the fritz.
Where'd you say Eric is?
Somewhere along the pipeline.
What about that hotheaded marshal, Sam Wilder?  I heard he was in the middle of this mess.
Sam?  We haven't seen him.
Really.  I thought maybe that was his snowmobile outside. (beat) By the way -- your truck also 'on the fritz?'
(blanching) Why?
It's out by the pumping station, shot full of holes.
Noting Anne Marie's distressed reaction to this news, he crosses to the door.
(continuing) Still nothing to tell me? (no reply) Suit yourself.

Eric limps further down from the mountains.  Corbett keep pace in front of him and his magnum.  As their altitude decreases, there is ever thicker vegetation. Their tracks in the snow stretch up behind them into the distance.  The magnificence and grandeur of the surroundi cannot be overstated.  Picture the most rustic, overwhelm wilderness imaginable, and then make it ten times larger.

The men's way is once again interrupted, this time by a sheer granite drop. The steep decline would be tough to negotiate with mountaineering equipment and proper footwe Corbett peers over the edge and shakes his head.
Have to backtrack, find another way down.
Forget it.  It would take days.
(assessing the drop) Going to be a bit of a challenge with handcuffs on.

Eric realizes he's right.  After some deliberation, Eric cautiously approaches him.  With the .357 cocked and read he undoes one of the cuffs, leaving them hanging from Corbett's wrist.  He then unthreads the nylon twine from Corbett's tarp.

Eric and Corbett are tied, belt to belt, with the nylon rope.  Corbett inches down first, feet spread for maximum footing, gloveless hands grasping at anything. Eric mimics Corbett's moves and follows the same path. Unable to grasp the rocks effectively, he stops and takes his gloves off.  Continuing, he winces -- the rock is col and sharp.  His hands are soon numb and bloody.  Even in dry, below-freezing air, Eric is sweating. He looks down and hangs on more tightly.  Sliding to leve ground two hundred feet below would pummel him to hamburg Corbett pauses and rests his cheek against the rocks.  Er is right above him.

Suddenly, Corbett's foot slips.  His right hand instinctively goes for a hold.  The dangling handcuffs sn on a protuberance, knocking him off balance. The fulcrum of Corbett's body leans out into the empty ai Eric moves down a little, braces himself and extends his leg, giving Corbett something to grab.  Corbett takes hol of Eric's shoe and tries to teeter back against the rock wall.  Adrenaline screams through Eric's system. Corbett looks up at Eric.  A careless move will send them both tumbling.  Eric clutches harder at the rocks and wai for the worst. After a long moment, Corbett regains his balance and lets of Eric's foot.  He continues his descent.  Eric lets out his breath and tries to swallow.  His mouth is as dry as granite.

Handcuffed again, Corbett hikes in front of Eric along th top of some foothills.  Now and again he glances behind, gauging Eric's weariness, waiting for a moment's carelessness.  Around them there is heavy vegetation now snow-covered sedge tussocks, knee-deep muskeg and twisted thickets that are treacherous and slow to tramp through. Above them, ominous clouds and sharp, cold winds are comi down from the north. But below, a mile ahead, the edge of the forest is like t hem of a great green garment stretching endlessly southwa The combination of altitude and latitude creates an amazingly sharp topographical dividing line.  Within a fe thousand yards, the landscape abruptly changes from scrub brush to thick coniferous forest.
Better get into those trees before that squall blows down.

Then, Corbett pauses as a walloping sound ECHOES across t foothills. Just ahead, two enormous bull moose are fighting.  They r each other with six-foot-wide antlers. Corbett stares, transfixed, admiring.
You talk about ecology -- there it is.
Eric turns, surprised at Corbett's unabashed awe. Catching the men's smell the moose bound away, and the sp is broken.

Viking Bob, Mitchell and LeMalle head somberly back to Cache.  They drive along a hydraulic gold mining sluice o nearby river and come into town. As the trappers park their jeep, some MINERS greet them, shouting over the ROAR of the water.
Where's Ben at?
You'll want to hear about it with a drink in your mitt.

Outside, a STORM rages.  LeMalle is drunk, but still able stuff himself with a thick steak.  Mitchell drums his fingers and listens to everyone talk.  With them at the b are the Miners, LOGGERS, CAT SKINNERS (bulldozer drivers) and some leathery WOMEN.
...Figures, Corbett getting hauled off by a Federal marshal. God almighty, how I hate the U.S. government.
We should pass a hat.  Send Corbett a few bucks.  We owe him.
Someone's hat comes off.  It quickly gets filled with bil
Government and business.  They ruined this state. (re Meyerling poster) Like that little weasel, for instance.
'People's Friend,' my lily-white -more-
WOMAN CAT DRIVER (Cont'd) butt.  I heard Northland got a conservation program, up along the pipeline.
Hold it.  Meyerling told me that stuff's nothing but P.R. for the TV and papers down in Juneau.
He's full of shit.  We got run out of there by some fuckhead driving a Northland truck.
Viking Bob hurries in and whispers something in Mitchell' ear.  Mitchell shoots LeMalle a look and gets up.  The threesome hastily exit, leaving behind the hat full of money.
Viking Bob, Mitchell and LeMalle stand in a quiet corner near the front door.
I called the cops in Fairbanks, see when Ben is standing trial. They don't know shit about Ben or Wilder!
Get the fuck out of here.
It's a three-hour flight.  They shoulda got there yesterday.
Maybe they went back to Devil's Cauldron.
Naah, Wilder knows we got friends in town.
That plane might've been to throw us off the track.  Remember the bait-and-switch Wilder pulled with the Eskimo and his truck?
Wilder still woulda made Fairbanks by now.  Fuck a duck! Ben musta got loose.
Okay, let's backtrack, try to pick up his trail.  You know the kid out on the pipeline that Wilder's buddies with?
(smiles) We were just talking about him.

The STORM brings gusting winds and below-zero temperature Eric and Corbett move through the storm in slow motion. Both recognize the need for a truce in the face of a comm enemy.  The snow and wind cut through their clothing like razors.  They poke around for dead wood with which to mak fire.  The trees are small and healthy; little is found.
(shouts over WIND) Just gather birch.  It'll smoke like hell, but it'll burn green.

Awestruck by the intensity of the storm, Eric tears branc from birch trees and piles them in Corbett's handcuffed arms. They hurry back to the nylon tarp, strung between two tre trunks, FLAPPING violently in the storm.  Hunching agains the wind, Eric pulls off his gloves and reaches in his pocket for some precious matches.  His fingers are so col he can't hold them, and he drops several in the wet snow. Angry, he shoots a look at Corbett. Corbett is holding hi hands inside his coat.  He pulls them out and quickly tak the remaining matches from Eric. Crouching down, back to the wind, Corbett grasps a match between his numb fingers and awkwardly strikes it.  He ho the flame next to the kindling.  It doesn't catch fire immediately.  Corbett lets the match burn out against his fingers.  He tries another match.  This time, a flame tak hold but could succumb to the wind at any moment. On his knees and elbows, Corbett nurses along the tiny fi Eric can't control his shivering.  He gets on his knees n to Corbett and holds his coat open to further baffle the wind.  Corbett keeps his hands cupped around the flame, n

caring that it's burning his skin.  Finally the fire begi to grow.  Relieved, Eric and Corbett look at each other w a glimmer of a grudging mutual respect. The fire, now unattended, is smoky as Corbett predicted, burns along nicely.

Corbett and Eric sit under the nylon shelter.  The STORM rages outside.  Eric empties his pockets of Eskimo potato reindeer lichens, bistsort sorrel and other plants for hi dinner. Corbett has fashioned a snare from his boot laces and a t branch, and placed some crushed roots as aromatic bait ne to a small animal burrow outside the shelter.  A squirrel sticks his nose out of the burrow to investigate. Corbett sits catlike, ready to pounce.  Eric grimaces as Corbett yanks on the snare and the squirrel's SQUEALS (OS abruptly cease.
Corbett pulls his dead dinner inside.
I need your pocket knife. (Eric hesitates) I have to eat, too.
After a beat, Eric pulls open the small blade on his Swis Army knife and pushes it with his foot to Corbett.  Smili Corbett admires the fancy knife.  Then, BELOW FRAME, he skins and guts his catch.
(continuing) Damn lucky this storm didn't blow down when we were on those baldheaded mountains.  It continues, we better stay put.
It could blow over tomorrow, too.
I'm still figuring: You're either real brave or real dumb.
I just want this over with.
(laughs) Where in hell Meyerling dig you up?
You know Meyerling?
Sure.  The People's Friend.  Kiss your ass with precision if there's a vote in it.

Corbett eats the squirrel Eskimo-style.  Raw.  He uses th knife like a native, too, holding the meat in his teeth, then expertly cutting off a mouthful with a quick slice. Eric stares, disgusted.  Off his look:
(continuing) Always eat your meat raw when the weather's cold.  Does you more good, long as the entrails look clean.
Corbett uses snow and the squirrel's fur to wipe the bloo from his face, then wipes the knife off and lays it, open next to his leg.
I'll hold onto that.
With a wry smile, Corbett pushes it back over to Eric. While Eric eats his dinner, Corbett listens to the STORM watches him eat.
Sure love to know where you fit in up here.
I'm here to do my job.
You want to fool yourself about that bullshit job, fine.  Damn shame you have to drag your girlfriend along.  You think a woman like that will be happy making moose stew for a man -more-
CORBETT (Cont'd) making your salary?  Look, I'll give you five grand.  Take the money and go home where you both belong.
Don't fucking insult me.
Corbett smiles -- maybe he's beginning to understand Eric

Folks come to Alaska for a real short list of reasons:  Money. Adventure.  Solitude.  Those cover most everyone.  But frontiers also draw another type of man.  One with a demon in his gut.  He comes to the edge of the world to face that demon, and lay it to rest.
Yeah?
Yep.  Sometimes they do, but usually they end up crazy or dead.
Eric ponders Corbett's words as he eats.
Anne Marie is frantic with worry.  She has the AM/FM RADI on for company.

...This is "Tundra Topics" on KFAR.  Remember, as the nights get longer, be sure to stay on a regular sleep schedule.  The depression from the coming of winter that doctors call 'Seasonal Affective Disorder' -- or 'Arctic Blue' to us lay folk -- is preventable.
Anne Marie tunes the radio to "Pipeline of the North" on KIAK.
(continuing) ...John Byers was hospitalized in Fairbanks today for an infection in an abscessed tooth.  Mr. Byers had a toothache and attempted to remove the tooth himself with a pair of pliers...

Suddenly, a BUMP rocks the Turtle.  Someone is outside. Startled, Anne Marie turns the lights off and looks out t window. No sign of a vehicle or a person.  As she pulls on her parka, she glances at the big rifle leaning against the wall, but doesn't touch it.
Her visitor, whoever it is, is behind the Turtle.  Anne Marie cautiously rounds the corner and stops dead.

A foraging GRIZZLY sniffs around, attracted by the smell fresh carrion -- Wilder.  Eight feet tall and eleven-hund pounds, it's used to having its way.  Right now, it's hungry. With a casual swipe of its paw, its massive claws punctur the Turtle's aluminum skin, popping open the door of the utility compartment.  The bear pokes its head inside, and Wilder's body slumps out into the snow.  The bear pushes the corpse with its snout.  Salivating, it prepares to di in. Anne Marie looks around, wondering what the hell to do nE Wilder's snowmobile is a few yards behind her, parked against the side of the Turtle.  She inches toward it. Testily, the bear looks up, SNIFFING loudly. Keeping her eyes on the bear, Anne Marie feels for the snowmobile ignition keys.  They're not there.  She feels around inside the saddlebags and finds three emergency ro flares. Anne Marie IGNITES the flares.  They illuminate the area with an eerie reddish glow.  She YELLS at the bear, wield the flares like Excalibur and moves forward. The bear, reluctant to leave so hearty a pre-hibernation meal, GROWLS and cocks its head back and forth to assess threat.  As Anne Marie inches ahead, the bear stands on h legs to its full height to meet the challenge.

Anne Marie tosses a flare toward the bear.  It grunts whe the flare hits it, and shuffles backwards.  Anne Marie throws another flare.  With a ROAR from hell, the bear charges.  Anne Marie falls back.  Still holding the last flare, she's forced into a crawl space under the Turtle.

Anne Marie tries to squeeze out the other side, but she's pinned in by the unevenness of the hard ground.  The bear swipes at her, its huge paw inches away.  Anne Marie jabs the paw with the flare, but that only makes the bear more quarrelsome. She twists around, looking for a defense.  Above her is t cabling from the generator to the circuit box for the Turtle's electrical system.  She tugs at it, but it won't budge.  The bear SNIFFS at Anne Marie with its big wet snout.  Anne Marie notices warning a sign on a control valve:
Grimacing, she tries to turn the valve.  After much effor it SNAPS and opens, releasing a stream of fetid sewage.

The bear gets a muzzle full of the stuff.  HOWLING unhappily, it backs away, GRUNTING and SNEEZING.  Greatly offended, its appetite gone, it lopes into the forest. Anne Marie squirms out from under the Turtle and, gagging from the horrible smell, pulls off her wet parka.

Wearing one of Eric's coats, Anne Marie stands in the cen of three similarly-sized trees.  A FLARE supplies the lig The big Remington rifle leans against the tree closest to her. She tosses one end of a hundred feet of nylon rope over a sturdy tree branch twenty-five feet from the ground.  The she throws the other end over an opposing branch and stretches the rope like a clothesline.

She attaches a second length of rope perpendicular to the first and throws it over a third tree branch, midway betw the other two.  She kneels and ties something BELOW FRAME the cross-length rope. Pulling mightily on the perpendicular rope, she hoists something heavy to the level of the branches.  The flare burns out, plunging the area into darkness. Anne Marie wraps the rope around the tree trunk and nervously tries to LIGHT another flare.  As she does, the forest seems closer, sinister, filled with lurking ogres. Seized with an instinctual fear, she grabs the rifle and runs back to the Turtle.

The storm has passed, leaving a fresh covering of powdery snow in drifts like sand dunes.  Eric and Corbett trek toward Devil's Cauldron through the ever-thickening fores Corbett has made them snow goggles by cutting slits in strips of tree bark worn like sunglasses.  Eric, using a tree branch as a walking stick, still limps on his sore ankle.  For the first time, he keeps the magnum stuck in waistband.
There's a cabin, maybe twenty miles south of here.
(kneels to adjust his ankle wrap) Too bad we're heading west.
There's a snowmobile. Inside a day we could be on the Yukon.  I got money there.  Remember that five thousand?  Make it ten.  Be smart.  Take it and walk away.
(bristling) You don't get it, do you?

Corbett takes advantage of Eric's poor peripheral vision from the visor by kneeing Eric in the face.  Eric falls backwards into the snow.  Corbett takes off like a jackrabbit.  Eric spits out some blood, shakes the stars of his eyes and yanks the .357 from under his coat.
(continuing) Stop!
