Corbett bounds through the snow, dodging trees and snow-covered rocks. Eric squeezes off a SHOT, and is startled by the recoil a the blast.  He scrambles to his feet and SHOOTS again. Corbett zigzags and disappears from sight over a snowbank
Corbett runs over a frozen stream, invisible under a cove of snow.  Suddenly, the ice SHATTERS under him.  Corbett immersed in frigid, waist-deep water.  He gasps from the sudden temperature drop.
hobbles after him, CUSSING bitterly to himself.
crawls to solid ground.  Disoriented from the shock to hi system, he rolls over to catch his breath.

Eric appears over a snowbank. Corbett tries to run, but his frozen, waterlogged legs fe like pig iron.  Stumbling and panting, he looks for a saf place to cross the stream.  Eric easily catches up to him Corbett sits in the snow, shivering.  He looks up as Eric trots over. Eric glares at Corbett and rubs the bruise on his cheek.
Nothing personal.  Just wanted to see what you'd do.
Noticing Corbett's sopping legs, Eric becomes furious.
(continuing) Have to get these wet things off.
You're not going to slow us down! Keep moving!
Inside of three hours you'd be dragging my dead carcass.
Fuming, Eric helps Corbett up.
The sun sinks below the horizon, creating across the mountains a spectacular show of color and shadows.  The w HOWLS.
Eric stokes a fire at the mouth of the shelter.  Corbett' pants and boots hang to dry from branches next to it.  He huddles under the tarp, covered by his coat, drowsy and listless.
Stay awake!  You want to go hypothermic?
If that means freeze my balls off, no thanks. (yawns) I'll be okay.
Eric examines him.  Corbett's skin is white and rigid, hi lips are pale blue.  He scowls at Eric.
(continuing) Told you I'm fine!
(holds up three fingers) How many do you see?
(irritable) What?!  Fuck off.  Save yourself.
You don't feel cold?
It's a spring day...

He starts to doze off.  The shivering he's been repressin now racks his body.  Eric sits him up, closer to the fire and puts his own parka over Corbett's shoulders.  With hi foot, Eric rolls some hot rocks bordering the fire closer
Corbett's legs.  Eric rubs his arms and hands, but it isn enough.  Eric loathes the specter of death, even Corbett' He shakes him, trying to keep him awake.
Wake up, goddammit!  You've got classic hypothermia -- crankiness, fatigue, can't feel your coldness.  Worst thing you can do is fade out.

Corbett is headed someplace far away.  Sighing, Eric turn him so his back faces the fire.  He unbuttons Corbett's shirt, then unbuttons his own shirt and lies across Corbe Eric gasps -- Corbett feels like a slab of ice.  Corbett' teeth chatter.  He's completely unconscious.
(continuing) One more thing -- this doesn't mean we're going steady.
Later, Corbett rests fitfully.  It could go either way. Eric chews on some roots and pokes at the fire to keep it lively.
It's night.  Some color has returned to Corbett's skin. Eric turns as Corbett mumbles and clutches at the front o his shirt.  His eyes open.  He tries to sit up, but he's weak.
Stay still.
Where's my ELT?
Emergency transmitter?  All your gear is back at Wilder's.
You got one?
It was blown up with the plane.
Too bad.  We'd be out of here in a few hours.
How?  Nobody this far north monitors that frequency until avalanche season. (beat) Besides, I'm surprised a tough guy like you uses fancy electronics.
I'm surprised a flat-ender like you knows cold-weather remedies.
Read a lot of adventure stories when I was a kid...
Corbett smiles.
I'm hungry.  Go kill me some dinner.
An appetite.  Maybe you won't die after all.
Hate to disappoint you.
The AURORA makes a dazzling display in the cold clear sky Below, the only light on the endless expanse of dark eart comes from the Turtle.
Flashlight in hand, wearing one of Eric's coats, Anne Mar refuels the generator.  Something catches her eye --
In the distance, headlight beams jostle along the Haul Ro
Anne Marie caps the diesel fuel can and stows it away.
(grinning) It's about time...
She hurries back into the Turtle.
Anne Marie brushes her hair and makes herself presentable
The vehicle gets closer.  It's the trappers' jeep.  It sl and parks on the Haul Road next to the Turtle.
Anne Marie peers out the window.  She gasps as she recognizes the jeep.  Ducking from sight below the window she grabs Eric's coat and hurries into the rear module.

Mitchell stays in the jeep.  Viking Bob and LeMalle get o and walk cautiously toward the Turtle. LeMalle stands midway between the jeep and the Turtle, cradling his carbine.  Viking Bob goes up the steps.
Anne Marie remembers something she should've taken with h the rifle.  Too late.  She hears Viking Bob's FOOTSTEPS ( come up the wooden stairs outside.
Viking Bob knocks on the front door.  He peers through th sheer curtain on the window, into the front module.
Hullo?
He shrugs to the others, then tries the door.  It's unlocked. Mitchell gets out of the jeep, spits and follows the othe in, his hand close to the Colt Peacemaker strapped to his leg.

Anne Marie climbs out a window in the back.  She closes i behind her just as Viking Bob pokes his head in the rear module. The trappers snoop around, noticing that the coffee pot i still warm, etc.  The emptiness is ominous.  LeMalle pick up the big Remington bear rifle.  He opens the breech to determine if it's loaded, and sniffs the barrel to see if
it's recently been fired.  Viking Bob notices the damaged radio.
Somebody left in a big hurry. (to LeMalle) Check outside.
LeMalle goes outside and shines his flashlight around.

In the back, Anne Marie drags an evergreen tree branch behind her to cover her tracks in the snow, then climbs i the utility compartment where Wilder's body was stored. A moment later, LeMalle comes around the corner.  He noti bear tracks and scat from the prior night's visit.
(calls out to others) Grizzly sign.  Looks fresh.
Viking Bob and Mitchell converge with LeMalle.  They poin their flashlights around, spotting footprints and marks going off into the woods.

Tense and silent, the trappers follow the marks.  A breez RUSTLES the needles of the evergreens around them.  They stop at the point the footprints end.  A rhythmic CREAKIN above them makes LeMalle shine his light upward.

The light REVEALS Wilder's feet swinging back and forth above their heads.  His body is suspended in the manner o trail cache.  Viking Bob lets out a startled grunt.  He a Mitchell shine their lights on Wilder's face.
It's Sam Wilder!
Musta wanted to keep him from the bears.  If Ben killed him, he sure as hell wouldn't hang him up like this.
Where's the kid?
Who gives a husky fuck?  Where's Ben?
The trappers look glumly at one another.
Anne Marie jams herself behind a pile of her photo equipment.  She stops as she hears the trappers' boots (O CRUNCH in the snow past her and go inside the Turtle.
The trappers peel off their overcoats.  They look around the comfortable surroundings.
I should get me a job with an oil company.
He sits on the couch and lays his scrimshaw and engraving tools out on the coffee table.  LeMalle helps himself in well-stocked larder.
I say we eat, torch this fuckin' thing, and move on.
LeMalle digs through the cupboards and comes up with a fr bottle of Scotch.
Go easy.
Cool out.  I ain't about to get blasted.

Flashlight in hand, gloriously drunk, LeMalle stumbles outside.  He crosses to the jeep to grab a box of Twinkie and, as long as he's at it, take a leak in a snowbank. Bleary-eyed, he notices the damage to the utility compartment inflicted by the bear. He walks to it, stepping over the bear scat.  He marvels the size and depth of the clawmarks.
Big mother musta wanted something real bad in here...
LeMalle tries the door, but it's jammed shut.  He tucks h flashlight under his arm and gives another tug.  This tim the door cracks open.
He peers through the opening and shines his flashlight in A pair of eyes stare back at him.

LeMalle jumps back, startled, and pulls out his knife. tries the door again.  It WRENCHES open... ...He's looking at his own face in one of Anne Marie's mirrored photo reflector boards. Letting his breath out, LeMalle pokes around the equipmen in the compartment.  Ever larcenous, he pulls a few items out, examines them, and, disinterested, leaves them in th snow.  Doing so, he comes close to uncovering Anne Marie, who sits motionless and terrified in the back of the compartment. Nothing in the compartment catches LeMalle's fancy.  Leav the door hanging open, he wanders away.
After he's gone, Anne Marie reaches over and closes the door.  She can hear the trappers' (OS) CONVERSATION insid
I know in my gut he was here. First light, we try to get scent of his trail.
Sighing, Anne Marie stuffs her hands inside her parka and tries to get comfortable.  It's going to be a long night.
Eric and Corbett wearily trudge through the woods.  Corbe has the tarp wrapped around him for extra warmth.  As he walks, he sniffs at one of Eric's Eskimo potato roots and takes a tentative nibble.
Used to see the natives eating roots when I was a kid in Nome.
Nome?  I figure you'd be a whaler, coming from there.

Told that's what our old man was. Planned on going to sea, me and Bob, 'til I read Jack London. Started trapping when I was ten. Mailed the furs to Sears.  Eight bucks for a skunk, three for a muskrat. (off Eric's look) That was fine money.
Killing wildlife not good enough anymore, so you go on to bigger and better things.
You got a knack for seeing things the way you want to see them.
They walk in silence.  Corbett tightens the tarp against cold air and looks at Eric.
(continuing) Don't judge me.  You're a joke, coming here from a fucked-up culture, telling us what to do!
Yeah, it is fucked up -- but it's not too late to keep that from happening here.

(temper flaring) All you do is keep folks from working the land, living like they're meant to.  You don't understand shit!  Trappers, hunters -- we're part of the environment.  Who's protecting us? (sourly) I've seen plenty like you.  So -more-
CORBETT (Cont'd) full of yourselves there's no room for other people's way of life.
What do you know about people? You live like an animal!  A savage goddamn throwback like you belongs out here, as far away from the rest of us as possible.
I'm real sad you don't approve of me.
He shoves Eric with his handcuffed hands.
(continuing) Tell me what I should do, Professor.  You got all the answers.  I shouldn't hunt? Fine, I'll just phone up and have a salad delivered.
Livid, Eric backs away and knocks Corbett's hands away fr him.
Don't push me..!
Cowardly bastard.  I'm in handcuffs and I still scare the piss out of you.

Eric smashes his fist into Corbett's face.  Corbett reels back, more surprised than hurt.  Eric moves in, furiously throwing punches.  Corbett plows his clenched fists into Eric's midsection, doubling him over.  Gasping, Eric rams his head into Corbett and they fall into the snow. Despite the handcuffs, Corbett gets a few blows in.  They wrestle fiercely, and Eric ends up on top of Corbett.  He about to throw another punch when Corbett looks up at him
(continuing) First you save my ass, now you want to kill me.  Make up your goddamn mind.
Eric lowers his fist and climbs off of Corbett.  Corbett gets up and they continue on their way in sullen silence.

Sunday morning.  Chimney smoke rises straight up in the still morning air and mingles with the wisps of fog hangi above the Devil's Cauldron valley. A scratchy RECORDING of a HYMN ("We Will Gather at the River") plays through a PA system, ECHOING forlornly off hills.  The PEOPLE of Devil's Cauldron walk through the n snow to the center of the settlement.  Some, older Women mostly, head for the dance hall, where the HYMN originate
The Women SING along with the HYMN.  They face a shelf holding the PA, a rusty TV and record player.  And, in fr of the shelf, an unmanned pulpit.
The Men, including Neff, split off from their mates and g into the Maqi.
Neff joins some other Men sweating on benches in the primitive steam bath.   Kenai sits closest to the fire. thick glasses are steamed up, but he finally looks warm.
Wilder's missing church services; you believe it?
I just as soon he stay gone. Fool could've got us all killed, arresting Ben Corbett here in town.

Exhausted, Corbett and Eric climb across the last set of foothills before the Devil's Cauldron valley.  The town comes into view below them; faintly the MUSIC carries fro below.  Corbett looks at Eric and breaks the silence:
What makes you so sure my boys won't be waiting for us?
They think you're in Fairbanks. If not, they still won't find you before the plane comes tomorrow.
Don't bet on it.
I already have.
You don't know how true that is.
Eric sweeps the snow from between two rocks and sits down
We'll wait here until nightfall. No fire, no tarp.
Corbett sits next to him.  After a long moment:
Didn't mean it, you being a coward.  You're a lot of things, but chickenshit isn't one of them.

Maybe...maybe not.  I'll tell you what scares me -- stumbling through life, like an ordinary jerk.  That's why I want to work on the front lines, where what I do means something. (beat) Soon as I got here, I realized my job was bullshit.  Oil company propaganda.  I was ready to leave, then I thought screw it, I'll outsmart them, do the work anyway. (beat) I don't know anymore.  Maybe I am fooling myself.  That's what I'm afraid of most of all.
Hell, I still get a knot in my gut every season, wondering how much longer I can go on.  No 'Home for Retired Trappers' that -more-
CORBETT (Cont'd) I ever saw.  We're like Eskimos -- get too old to be useful, we're left on the ice to die.
The men listen to the faint MUSIC echoing through the sil foothills.
(continuing; softly) My wife used to go to chapel on Sundays.  See her friends, 'cause I was away so much. (beat) Should've been home that day. She'd be getting dressed right about now...
Eric glances over as a look of utter desolation crosses Corbett's face.
The trappers file out the front door.
My guess is he's loose and heading for Chukfoktulik.  He'll need supplies; that's the closest settlement without a lawman.
LeMalle carries his booty with him.  Viking Bob looks at disapprovingly as he puts the big Remington rifle in the jeep.
I ain't gonna leave a seven- hundred-dollar Remington behind.
(exasperated) What you gonna do with it?  Large bore's for shit on small game.
Not in the right hands it ain't.

To demonstrate, he rapid-fires several SHOTS from the hip taking the radio antenna off the roof of the Turtle, shattering panes of glass in an accurate succession, and blasting the door latch off the utility compartment.
Pleased, LeMalle slams back the bolt, ejecting a spent shell.  He glances curiously at the door of the utility compartment and starts toward it.
(continuing) Thought that door was open last night...
Quit fucking around.  Get in.
LeMalle climbs into the back of the jeep.  With Viking Bo driving, they pull away.
Grinning maliciously, LeMalle hangs the Remington out the window as they retreat.  Taking careful aim, he SHOOTS.

LeMalle's bullet hits the metal fuel tank of the generato The kerosene fumes EXPLODE, splattering BURNING KEROSENE the rear module of the Turtle. The trappers don't slow down to enjoy the show.  Viking B hurries on to more important business.

As soon as the SOUND of the jeep fades away, Anne Marie clambers out of the utility compartment.  Haggard and num with cold, she helplessly watches as the fire ravenously devours the rear module.  Shielding her face from the flames, Anne Marie reaches under the accordion cover betw the modules.  With great effort, she unbolts the coupling bracket.

Anne Marie STARTS the engine, SLAMS it into gear, and lurches the front module away from the burning rear modul She shuts the motor off and, trying to hold back the tear watches the rear module BURNING.

Bone weary, Eric and Corbett walk toward town, staying on the outskirts to avoid being seen.  They look at one anot -- this moment seemed impossible not very long ago.  No o seems to notice as they limp into Wilder's cabin.

It's dark.  Eric locks Corbett up in the holding cell, no noticing that Corbett seems almost pleased to be there. blocks the windows, pumps up the pressure on the white ga lantern and heads back outside again.
Neff pries himself from his MTV to answer a KNOCK at the door.  Eric hobbles in.  Neff notes Eric's weatherbeaten condition.
You don't mind me saying, Mr. Desmond, you look like hell.
Have you heard anything from the girl staying with me, Anne Marie?
Not a damn thing.  What's going on?  Mr. Meyerling was here, all steamed up, looking for you.
Look, Neff, I've got Ben Corbett with me --
-- Here?!  Where's Wilder?
Back at my place... he, uh, broke his leg.
If Corbett's men find out --
-- I'm putting him on the plane to Fairbanks, eleven tomorrow.
Jiminy Christmas. (beat) What do you want from me?
Corbett ruined my two-way.  Go to my place on the Haul Road, tell Anne Marie I'm okay and to sit tight.
I'll go at dawn.
Thanks.  Don't tell anyone you saw me.
After Eric goes, Neff closes his door and bolts it.

The temperature dips as the winds shifts and blows down f the north.  Another storm approaches.  The temperate days last week seem ages ago. Kenai, Neff, and other TOWNSMEN batten Devil's Cauldron d for the STORM.  Kenai is bundled up in the cold.  The men tighten guy wires on the radio tower, windmills and cache bring firewood indoors; close off unused rooms in the general store and spa.  Then Neff and Kenai split off fro the others.

Via a catwalk, Neff and Kenai climb up into the ceiling struts above the partitioned cubicles in the spa to caulk roof leak with pitch.  Neff is sullen from his conversati with Eric. Kenai, however, is smiling at Neff.
Why the smirk?
Bet I could make some money turning Ben Corbett in.  Maybe more for lettin' him loose. (off Neff's flustered look) I was up in my cache.  Saw the Northland man come talk to you.
You're out of your greedy goddamn mind.
Corbett coming here stinks of trouble.  We should make the best of it before it turns around and bites us in the ass.
Stay out of it.
Eric stirs a pot of beans on the cookstove.  Corbett watc from the cot in the cell.
Talk to that good-looking girl of yours?
You broke the radio, remember?
(smiles) I'm sure she's fine.  Seemed like a clever kid.
Corbett sits up as Eric hands him a plate of beans.

(continuing) You were real resourceful out there.  Got me thinking of this perimeter man, froze all his fingers one winter.  So he hacked the tips off and sharpened the exposed bones.  Gets along better than ever.  Yeah, maybe I underestimated you.
I liked you better frozen.  You didn't talk so much.

You're damn lucky, glimpsing this country before it's ruined, gone for good.  You saw wonders you'd only dreamed of.  That alone makes you different than the sorry bastards back where you came from, because you have dreamt them.
Corbett sees he's hit a nerve with Eric.

(continuing) Remember that demon in the gut? Sometimes it's nothing more than wondering if the so-called civilized life has bred the balls and brains out of you.  That's what you want out of this, isn't it?
All I want want is you in jail --
A KNOCK at the door interrupts.  Eric lowers the flame on the gas lantern and peers out through a corner of the cardboard in the front window.  Frowning, he cracks the d open and slips outside.
It's Neff and Kenai.  Neff looks guiltily at Eric.
(explaining) He saw you and Corbett come in...
Dixie's waiting at the infirmary. She'll put a splint on that injured leg.
Eric is skeptical of Kenai's concern.
Don't let him fool you.  Real reason he's here is to buy Corbett's traps.
Eric looks at Kenai, then at Neff.  Neff nods that it's okay.  As extra precaution, Eric handcuffs Corbett's righ wrist to the frame of the cot inside the cell.
(to Kenai) Okay.  You can talk to him.  But I'll keep the keys with me.
Outside the wind HOWLS.  Eric enters and walks into the hallway connecting the bath partitions.  A hand grabs his arm.  Startled, he turns around. It's Dixie, wearing a threadbare flannel robe.
Earl says you get discount. Twenty-five dollar.
Eric shakes his head -- typical Kenai.  He gives her thre tens.  She smiles and leads Eric toward the "infirmary." It's actually a bath partition outfitted with an examinin table and a first-aid kit.
Neff paces nervously.  Corbett smiles at him and Kenai.
(apologetically) Look, Ben, we don't want any trouble.  The kid's got the key, and besides, he looks edgy enough to use that magnum he's carrying.
Relax.  I'll get loose in time.
Any traps you don't want, I'll pay cash money.
Guess someone should use them. Open the bottom drawer in Wilder's desk.  My kit's in there.  Might as well unload everything.

Kenai tugs on the drawer.  It's locked.  Undaunted, he jimmies it open with a knife.  Neff groans.  Kenai goes t throw Corbett the duffel bag, but Neff grabs it.  He chec for weapons, pulling out a hunting knife.  Satisfied, he hands Corbett the bag through the bars. With his free hand, Corbett digs through his belongings: clothing, freeze-dried provisions, jerky, paperback books He looks up and shrugs.

Eric's ankle is in a resin cast.  His foot rests on a sto While waiting for the cast to set he soaks in the bathtub hot towel draped over his face.  Above him, on a wall bracket, a closed circuit TV plays a war-surplus PORNO FI The door CREAKS open and Dixie comes in.  She impassively checks his cast -- which is interesting, as she's now wearing panties, clog shoes and nothing else.  Eric takes the towel off his face and sits up, astonished.
I wash your back for you.  You will like it.
Before Eric can protest, the door OPENS again.  It's Meyerling.  He snaps his fingers at Dixie to shoo her and she scurries away.
I hate to interrupt playtime, but why the hell are you caught up in a local matter when I gave you express instructions to the contrary?!
Cut the shit, Leo.  I might need your help...
Consisting of a handful of sod-roof cabins, mostly bars, Chukfoktulik is a way station in the coniferous forest, sixty miles southeast of Devil's Cauldron.

With the seats pushed back, LeMalle peels the town's lone WHORE out of her parka.  He's got the motor running for warmth.  Her gold tooth glints in the light from the building next to them.  The locating screen on the beat-u radio beacon receiver bolted to the dash GLOWS phosphorescent green.
They got nice beds upstairs, honey.
I'm standin' guard duty. Besides, rather spend the room money on sloppy seconds.
Over the sound of LeMalle's exertions there begins an insistent succession of BEEPS.  The Whore looks over LeMalle's shoulder at the locating device.
Hey, Tiger --
LeMalle turns and immediately loses interest in the Whore Pushing her off of him, he blows the jeep's HORN three times.
Eric and Meyerling are in the middle of an argument.
...I won't let a killer walk!
Alleged killer.
What does this matter to you?
(sneering) You can't see past your lousy little assignment, sniffing around the pipeline.  The few voters there are in this district look up to Corbett, and I'm not about to alienate them.
I should release Corbett because you want some votes?

This miserable wilderness is a state of the union.  Policy's made here the same way as in the civilized world: at the ballot box.  That's the beauty of it -- these icebox cowboys are living a century too late.  Get them on your side, it's like buying Manhattan for beads.  With a handful of votes you control the greatest frontier since white men stumbled onto the New World.
Some day these people'll wake up, and you'll be the first one they'll run out of here.
Eric's attention turns to a rhythmic INTERFERENCE on the screen.  There are three short bursts, followed by three long bursts.  Something about it is very familiar. Scowling, he sits up.
(continuing) Shit... (to Meyerling; distracted) Do what you have to.  So will I.
Eric climbs out of the water and pulls his pants on.

Kenai sorts through the tangle of Corbett's traps.   The door bursts open and Eric hobbles in.  Gun drawn, Eric unlocks the cell door.  He rips Corbett's shirt open. Looking around, he sees Corbett's duffel bag sitting by t cot.  Digging through it, he finds at the bottom of the b an ELT with a small red LED flashing on it. Furious, he flings it against the wall, smashing it.
The green dot on the screen and rhythmic BLEEP go suddenl dead, just as Viking Bob and Mitchell run up to the jeep.
Northwest.  Devil's Cauldron.
LeMalle dumps the half-naked Whore out onto the snow. Viking Bob starts the jeep and they roar off.
Eric shoves Kenai and Neff out the door.
What's wrong?
Just stay out of my face until I'm gone!
He slams the door.  Corbett smiles his Cheshire smile.
(continuing; picks up ELT) Emergency transmitter?  What happened to signal mirrors or two-tone smoke fires?
Lets us watch each other's backs over a wide area.  Only thing messed me up this time was getting arrested in the baths. ELT was in my duffel bag, not around my neck where it should've been.
No way they'll find you on a five-minute signal.  And no way -more-
ERIC (Cont'd) they'll get here in eight hours in this weather, unless they're right around the corner.
They haven't disappointed me yet.
Fat, dry snowflakes pour through the still air.  Gloomy clouds hang immediately overhead.  Visibility is ten feet the temperature is below zero.

It's 5:30 AM.  Sitting at Wilder's desk, Eric pries the t from some bullets and dumps the gunpowder into a styrofoa cup. He rings the top of the cup with bluetip matches, th seals it with masking tape.  Watching him from the cell, Corbett smiles.
Flashbomb, eh?

Eric doesn't answer.  He pulls on a heavy overcoat of Wilder's.  Putting the unused bullets back in Wilder's de Eric finds Corbett's .44 magnum.  He puts it and some speedloaders full of .357 hollowpoints in his pockets.

Eric hobbles across town to the hot springs under cover o the early hour and heavy snowfall.  He paces out several circuitous routes from the rental cabins to the airstrip the edge of town, pausing now and again along the way. He hears a door SQUEAK open and someone COUGH nearby, so stands motionless in the snow. Bundled in wool blankets, Kenai trundles down to his outhouse. After Kenai passes by, Eric sneaks inside the spa.  He climbs up into the catwalk. As Kenai goes back to his cabin, he notices that the anti bear traps on display in front of the general store are missing.  Suddenly, Eric grabs him and pulls him into the spa doorway.
Eric's unexpected appearance startles Kenai.
I need to rent a cabin.
What's the problem with Sam Wilder's place?
Will you rent me a cabin, or not?

Pretty clever:  If the trappers got that signal beacon and get here in time, Sam's is the first place they'll look.  They may figure you're waiting for an airplane, so you can't stay in the shack by the airstrip.  Last place they'd expect you is on the far side of town. (shakes his head) I can't afford any trouble --
(takes out all his cash) -- Here's a hundred dollars.  And if you or anyone else will back me up on this --
(grabs money) -- Forget it.  And try not to bleed on my throw rugs. (walks away, then turns back) Why do this?
If you have to ask, you wouldn't understand.
Outside, there is the high-pitched WHINE of a snowmobile (OS) driving into town.  Eric cautiously follows the SOUN
He listens as the vehicle cuts across town toward Neff's house.  The snowfall is too thick to see who it is.  Eric
moves in as close as he dares.  The ENGINE stops (OS) and FOOTSTEPS crunch up Neff's driveway.
A person in a hooded parka stands on Neff's stoop, about knock.  Magnum drawn, Eric suddenly appears from the curt of falling snow.  He shoves the person against the side o the house.
It's Anne Marie.  She gasps.  Seeing Eric, she's more ang than relieved.  Eric puts the gun back in his waistband.
Eric!  Why aren't you in Fairbanks?
He pulls her away from Neff's doorstep.  Her anger dissolving, she wraps her arms around him.
(continuing) Oh, Christ, sweetheart.  Four days!  I thought you were dead, or worse.
You can't stay here.  Go back to the Turtle.  I'll meet you back there in a few hours.
(stung by his coolness) What's going on?
I'll tell you everything later.
Where's Corbett?
Here.  A transport plane is due at eleven.  Once I put him on it, it's all over.
So what's the problem?
There isn't one, unless Corbett's men get here before the plane does.
Anne Marie grasps the situation with a sickening clarity.
Let the people here handle it. It's their marshal Corbett killed!
has been eavesdropping on the conversation through his window.  The news about Wilder stuns him.
Please, Anne Marie, you being here only complicates things.
I'm staying.
Eric knows she won't relent.
Take the snowmobile, park it behind Wilder's cabin.
Sighing, she STARTS the snow machine.  Most of her photo gear is lashed to the saddlebags.  As she pulls away, Eri limps back to Neff's house and knocks on the door. INT.  NEFF'S HOUSE
Shaken, Neff opens the door and lets Eric in.
I was just on my way to your ladyfriend's, but I guess she found you.
Yeah.  Sorry I barked at you last night.
I'm the one should be sorry... Goddamn Kenai, always out for a score.  I never should've let him go over there.
I'd sure like that favor you offered a while back.
Neff gets a seasick look on his face.
Look, Mr. Desmond, I didn't count on it turning this ugly.
What are you talking about?
Bastards killed Sam, you think they won't kill the rest of us?
There'll be three, four men at the most.  I have some backup, nothing will happen.
I'm real sorry.  In a while, you're gone from this country. But we live here.  No one wants to mix it up with those hombres.
Neff opens the door for Eric.
(angry) You don't care enough about Sam to --
-- Sam Wilder was my cousin. He's why I came to Alaska.  All his letters, saying what a paradise it is.  But me ending up dead won't do Sam a lick of good.
Anne Marie waits in front as Eric hobbles up.  She looks his bad ankle.
You're hurt.
Nothing broken.  C'mon, we have to hurry.
He leads her inside.
Corbett is calmly reclining on the cot in the holding cel
Could've told you no one would help...
Seeing Anne Marie, he smiles.
(continuing; to Anne Marie) Maybe you can talk sense into your boyfriend.
Shut up!
(to Anne Marie) Either way, you better clear out. I don't want anyone innocent getting harmed.
This comment has the intended effect on Anne Marie.  Angr Eric throws Corbett a coat.  Corbett puts it on.  Reachin through the bars, Eric cuffs Corbett's hands together.
We're moving.  Let's go.
As they exit, Corbett's sardonic look makes Anne Marie shiver.

The ten-by-ten cabin is furnished with two sagging cots, beat-up color TV set, a cookstove and a half-drum heat stove.  Built into the rear wall is a rustic dumb waiter that once lowered perishables into the icy waters of a now-dry stream. Eric checks his watch.  6:15 AM.  He bolts the door and blocks the windows, opening one enough to let sound in fr outside.  He extinguishes the Benman lantern and douses t fire in the heat stove so no smoke will emit from the chimney.  Anne Marie slumps into the corner next to the d waiter.
You'll catch a chill by that dumb waiter shaft.  Sit on the cot. (hands her the .44) Keep this pointed at him if I get preoccupied.

Anne Marie reluctantly takes the huge gun.  Trying to all her fears, Eric sits and brushes the hair from her face. Corbett intently watches them.  Before he can say anythin Eric shoots him a cold look.  Corbett stays quiet.

A pall hangs over the town.  People know to stay inside. Time crawls by. In his house, Neff, for once, has his TV turned off.  He tries to read and listens for sounds outside. In the spa, water DRIPS somewhere.  All the stalls are empty. In his sod house, Kenai looks out his one tiny window at curtain of snow.  Dixie comes up behind him and puts her hands on his shoulders.  He looks up at her, glum. In Wilder's empty cabin, his belongings are scattered abo as if expecting his imminent return. In the rental cabin, Eric checks his watch.  10:45 AM.

The sound of a MOTOR grows in volume, then abruptly cease The trappers' jeep APPEARS in the snowfall on the road in town.  It coasts quietly in and stops behind the cover of woodpile across from Wilder's cabin. The trappers get out of the jeep.  LeMalle has Eric's Remington, Mitchell has his Peacemaker, and Viking Bob carries LeMalle's old carbine.  Mitchell spits.  It's so cold outside that the spittle freezes and CRACKS before i hits the ground. They fan out and approach Wilder's cabin.
The cabin comes more clearly into view as the trappers mo closer.  There is no sign of life.  Viking Bob gestures f the others, now positioned on either side of the cabin, t crouch down for cover.
(calls out) Ben?  Ben Corbett?
No response.  Carbine held at his hip, Viking Bob walks u to the door and, with a mighty kick, BREAKS it in.
Viking Bob points the carbine at an empty room.  He notic however, Corbett's duffel bag on the floor of the cell.

The trappers march through town like an advancing army, looking for some sign of Corbett.  LeMalle stops to dig through his pockets for some food.  All he comes up with the stump of a candy bar.  Viking Bob looks at him impatiently.
Look, we pull Ben's ass out of the fire, I'll get you a whole damn crate of Snickers bars.
(insulted) I'm right fuckin' here with you.

To prove his point, LeMalle trots from dwelling to dwelli looking through windows and letting himself in through an unlocked door.  This proves fruitless, so he lets out a frustrated YELL.  Pointing the Remington skyward, he lets off a couple thunderous SHOTS that ECHO back off the foothills.

Hearing the shots, Eric pushes Anne Marie against the flo Cautioning her to stay put, he crawls to the window and tries to see through the snowfall.  After a moment of silence, from outside, not too far away:
Ben!  Speak out before I torch every dump in town!
Eric points the magnum at Corbett.
Answer and I'll shoot!
You kill me, you sign your death warrant. (re Anne Marie) And hers.
Viking Bob and Mitchell come running over to LeMalle. LeMalle fires another couple SHOTS for emphasis.
(calls out) You hear me?  Ben?
(to LeMalle) Ease off.  We do this my way.
He and the others strain their ears for a clue.
(continuing; calls out) Whoever's holding Ben Corbett, listen to me: we just want to know he's okay.  He is, nobody gets hurt.
His mind racing, Eric stares at Corbett.  Despite the freezing temperature of the room, he's sweating.
They know I'm here.  I don't say something, they'll plow this town under.  You willing to accept that responsibility?
Setting his resolve, Eric drags Corbett to the window.  H pushes the barrel of the magnum against Corbett's cheek.
Say you're okay.  Tell them I'll kill you if they rush us.
Anne Marie bites her lip and tries to maintain a brave front.  Despite the gun in his face, Corbett remains calm
(shouts through window) Bob?
Hearing Corbett's voice, the trappers spin around, trying ascertain its direction.
Relax.  I got a nervous man here with a magnum up my nose.
The trappers follow his VOICE toward the rental cabins.
You in one piece?
I'm fine.  Look forward to seeing you...
Count on it.
Eric pulls Corbett away from the window.  He shoots a loo at Anne Marie.  They're in a bind and she knows it.
LeMalle grabs Viking Bob's arm.
(to Viking Bob) Sweet-talk won't get shit. (calls out) Choose it, asswipe -- cut Corbett loose, or soon as you come outside, I put a fuckin' bullet through your eye!
Eric glances at Corbett, whose grim look certifies LeMall boast.

Snow's to their advantage, kid. You can't see them, but soon as that plane comes, they'll sure as hell know where we're going. Wise up.  Take me to the Yukon. I'll give you that money and guarantee you'll walk away.
Why offer a buyoff with your gunmen waiting outside?
The time has passed for men like them and me.  I know it.  But they're still fighting for survival, like cornered animals. That's why they'll kill you. -more-
CORBETT (Cont'd) (smiles) Be rude to let that happen after you kept me from freezing back there.
Anne Marie tries to hide how tempted she is by Corbett's offer.
(to Eric) He's right about the snow.  We're blind.
Eric sighs -- is she against him, too?  From outside:
Ben?
The trappers are obviously much closer.  Eric signals to Corbett not to answer.

Eric and Corbett face the window.  They don't notice as A Marie quietly shimmies outside through the narrow dumb waiter shaft to the back of the rental cabin.  Eric turns gasping as he realizes she's gone.  Corbett smiles sardonically.
At least your girl had the sense to jump ship.  Too bad she's the only one small enough to fit through that dumb waiter.
Using the cover of the snowfall, Anne Marie circles aroun the outside edge of town toward Wilder's cabin.  She take some of her photo gear from the snowmobile.
Unaware of Anne Marie's maneuver, the trappers wait for a response from Corbett.  None comes.  Viking Bob places a calming hand on LeMalle's shoulder.
Just wait, we don't know what this guy's up to.  Ben'll let us know what to do.

With a camera bag slung over her shoulder, Anne Marie cli up the metal antenna tower behind Neff's house on the edg of town. She grits her teeth and fights back a wave of vertigo. The ground disappears from sight, hidden by the snow and fog. Fifty feet up, she attaches her infrared video camera to tower crossbars and, using a length of coaxial cable, hoo its RF output to the feedline of the community TV antenna
Eric looks at his watch.  10:55 AM.
A CRACKING twig behind the cabins gets the trappers' attention.  Clutching his rifle, LeMalle goes to investigate.
as he probes through the snow, listening.  He reaches the edge of the woods and, finding nothing, returns to the others.
Anne Marie crouches behind a tree, twenty feet behind LeMalle.  After a moment, she tiptoes back toward the ren cabin.

Eric and Corbett turn as Anne Marie's camera bag suddenly drops from the dumb waiter shaft.  Anne Marie wriggles ba inside.  Before Eric can say anything, she puts her finge over his mouth.  She turns on the TV set and tunes it to channel 3.

A fuzzy IMAGE comes into view.  It's Devil's Cauldron fro the vantage of Anne Marie's infrared video camera.  The falling snow shows up as a translucent yellow wash over t scene.
